Entry.0:
Lieut M. S. Stanley Jan 1/17 15

O.C. Jan Reinf?? 1917

Arrived last night at 11 pm at Thiroul with Gill. Local hotel keeper delighted to be able to put us up. Mrs Hunter was awfully good to us. This morning was one of your Australian hot humid days. We started to climb the Bulli Pass. It was hot work & we were delighted to avail ourselves of a motorist offer of a ride. I had previously met him at the Fitzroy Falls.The scene from the top of the Pass is charming. From the Lookout an excellent view of the coast is seen & also the coastal towns. The afternoon we spent with the Bliths at Austenmere. It rained like fury but the swim was enjoyable & also the table chatter afterwards, arrived back again in Sydney at 11pm.
Entry.1: Hung around my tent all day expecting to see cousin Alice, did a little enveloping & slept well. Alice came along about 8 pm with a Miss Smith. Had some supper & took her home to the Peoples Palace.
Entry.2: Our men commenced work on explosives. Drivers did not go to stables.
Entry.4: we did not go to being 'duty co'. I reckoned we could continue & go to Bondi this afternoon, it is a burning hot day & this was done. Our C.S.M. took a party down, 'tramed' it both ways. Muster roll call at 5.45 pm showed 40 men absent, I met some of them later in town. Went to William's during the evening. Gill left camp earlier & during the period before my return 11pm they were chasing round for us expect to be paraded
Entry.5:
Hot day slept during afternoon, had a ride with Sgt Dunn to Maroubra during the morning. I rode "Old Taylor" he seems to have been knocked about lately & had a skin wound on the "off" fore foot. It was too hot to get a really good view of Maroubra but we had a good cruise over the hills.

Strange brightly coloured Beetles were mating & I found some beautiful spiders.

Went to sleep & didn't wake up till 7.15 pm to late for church or Mess Capt Calder is a strange colt. he is Camp Officer today.

My Mother
Entry.6:
17

Went out to Maroubra with Mr Partlin to make arrangements regarding a 'B' Co Bivouac. The day simply steamed one. This Major would not give his consent owing to a depot concert on Thursday next.

During the evening I walked to Mrs Shaw at a small comfort Bureau near the Opera House. what a wonderful woman she is, working simply for the soldiers & has done so for over two years.

To all the lads in Khaki she will give a cup of tea, milk, coffee, anything which will show them that she cares. Men have referred to her whilst fighting at Ypres. It's good to feel that some one cares for us. I chatted with her for quite 2 hours.
Entry.8:
Jan 16/17

Tickets for Concert have sold very well our men are bringing 2 & 3 people each. During the afternoon I went down to see how the hall was going. It looked simply splendid, the chaps had laced leaves thro the iron work of the ceiling. We fell in on the parade ground at 7 pm, it was nice & cool & at 7.15 pm headed by the Engineers Band. We left the Depot arriving at the Hall at 7.30 pm quite a great number of "B" co friends were at the door & after telling the men of the 12 pm leave. I broke them off & we found our friends & went into the Hall. We had approx 600 present. The Major (Hockings) & Capt Wallace arrived about 7.45. The Misses Blight's were my guests about 8 pm we started. Each item was encoded & I had to cut them out. I played for Don Wilson & Miss Williams respecting "Sunshine of Your Smile" & "Lifes Epitome" 'B' C's war song went well being sung by Temple (?) Simpson. A table was reserved for the officers but I had so many people to meet & handshke that I didn't fit much supper. The food was provided by our women folks & they did it right well. Tom make room for the tables we had a porttion of it in the open air. About 10.45 pm I did my 'stunt' & after a short chat I

19

did a lot more handshaking with the people of our lads - The Major congratulated us on our concert - Gill had to take my guests down to the station - jolly good luck for them. Everybody enjoyed themselves thoroughly.

Today the men finished filling in there allotements.
Entry.9:
Kit inspection after 9am parade it was quickly carried out. I filled in the mens pay books & made arrangements for final issues - to be done tomorrow. The Major made arrangements for an open air concert but it rained like fun - hard luck. Mess dinner to night was awfully good - met Miss Brain. Hamilton is off to the flying school. 

Friends showed me the plan of the lines of communication for Anzac. Sapper Black is absent from Parade - Made out my allotment. I am to draw 6/- including mess allowance.
Entry.10:
Served out final issue to our men, it is a strenuous job, all afternoon, they were marking their gear.

111

21
Entry.11:
Men were marking their gear all morning.

Went out to the Moores at Wharoonga North Syd met Mr & Mrs & enjoyed a yarn & a game of tennis.
Entry.12: Stayed in camp, heat awful so I slept most of the day. Intended to go to church but fell asleep.
Entry.13:
I arranged all orders for a bivouac just ending took all day. Couldn't get meany tools. Depot is practically without. Advance party went out under Sgt Collins by car, also a number of tools, & a party under C.P.L. Gibbons for guard. Mr Pantlin & myself went out during the morning to give the work a start.

An accident occurred to Don Robinson en route . The leading horse stumbled & pinned him under it. He was able to continue on duty.

Tried to catch a snake but missed it.

IV

23
Entry.14: On 6.30 parade I cleaned up our lines, collected mens caps & stowed same in Orderly tent, lifted tent floors & rolled Blankets & placed Kit's under line police, marched out from Depot at 9.20am, halted at Daceyville, arrived at Maroubra about 10.45am, everthing settled & work commenced at 2pm. the day was not too hot. Tea was a little late, swimming parade at 6.15pm. Mr gave us a short talk on the beach on the Galipoli landing, arrived at bivouac about 9.20pm. the night was fine & a light breeze kept the mosquitos away. We slept in the open.
Entry.15:
Swimming parade at 6.15am & Fatigues told off Black operated the cooker tip top. Sergeants messed with us. Breakfast was 1 hr late due to delay in getting away from depot. The day was fine. Col Warden & Major Hockings payed us a visit also O.C. of C Co Lieut Hoptown. Killed a snake on swimming Parade about 8.30pm Night fine NCOs class gave a display of bombing & flares. Trouble occurred on morning Swimming Parade but Lt Gill fixed it up

 

25
Entry.16:
Early morning parade taken up in cleaning up bivouac. Horses for transport arrived at 9am.

Moved off about 10am, & arrived at depot hot & sopping at 11.30am dismissed men & had a shower.

Remained in camp all afternoon read Harold Chapin's book Soldier & dramatist
Entry.17: Remained in camp most of the day and read Cobb's book "The red Glutton" got tired of it. Went to Pitt St church during the morning, it was hot & sultry & I felt very tired.
Entry.18:
Changed into another tent this morning. Duty Co today Saw Capt Wallace regarding duty next week end - couldn't get out of it. Cpl Hodgsen I also interviewed regarding his papers. He is absolutely the man I know, saw Capt Wallace & he intends to deal with him tomorrow. After mess we were visited with the heaviest rain & wind storm I have ever experienced. our tents were shaken heavily. The tools from Bivouac were returned today & were allright.

VI

 

27
Entry.19: Went out to Thompsons Foundry to test some explosives & their effect on cast iron blocks €” with Gilespie I enjoyed quite a great time burst up some chunks weighing a ton Came back with a ripping headache, went to bed early €” slept in my clothes
Entry.20:
Got up at 2.45 am & went down to the boat to see Mr Farrow away 1700 troops embarked, it was a great scene & I quite enjoyed it. The streamers were beautiful How brave the women folks are. I'm glad my Mother will not have to pass thro it. Went down the stream & returned in a launch about 11am. Farrow & Davies were quite pleased to get away. We are the next company to embark & I saw quite a number of tips to observe when my men embark. Cliffe, Macauliff, Gow & Robinson embarked on the same boat.

Received Book from Margaret Roberts & also Freda sent socks. Miss Dumas also wrote & Mrs Stone.
Entry.21:
Had chg of the C of E parade this morning - dreary sermon.

Today I received a pair of socks from Iris Whitworth & a letter from Miss Roberts of East Adelaide. The Stone children also wrote. I enjoyed a real good laugh at Teddy's, it's pleasant to hear from the kiddies. I intended to go to the Theatre tonight but really I had forgotten how quickly the week was going. Gill built a bridge

VII

 29

over the wide Gap this morning & it looked pretty good, enjoyed a good yarn with the Major this afternoon relative to our work.

Sgt Campbell came into my tent & we enjoyed a yarn over New Zealand. He was born in Wanganui & we had many mutual friends.
Entry.22:
Had a row with the Q.M. Capt Tinbury is absolutely unjust & has created a lot of trouble by assuming his department to be infallible.

The Major complained that during his morning walk he had seen a rabble, I butted into Hawkins (Sgt of the drivers) & installed Deacon to have control. Went up to the Moores of during the evening, they are awfully decent & I quite enjoyed myself, arrived back at camp at 12 midnight. Miss Moore is quite a pretty girl & I quite enjoy her company. Mr Moore is an Honourable & used to be Minister for Lands etc.
Entry.23:
Not much doing during the day. Went to "Mum Dawson at night, lost my ticket in under 10 minutes but they permitted me to go on. Met Lucas during the play. he has joined the E.O.T.s Went down to the wharf to have a look at the "Osterley"

VIII

 31
Entry.24: Duty company, attended the parades 6.30 & 9am. went to Pitt St during the morning. Sermon good €” "Effect of religion on national life" by Mr N J Cocks, my companion was Deacon. During the afternoon I went to Bronte had a surf & a bath in the sun, saw the surf club rescue a couple of men, the current was pretty strong. It did me good to get away from the Depot, during the evening I wrote letters & enjoyed a yarn with our officers.
Entry.25:
Received confidential orders respecting the of our men & conduct of same aboard. Called on the Engineer comforts people (Mrs Adams) & enjoyed quite a good chat with her.

I am duty officer this evening & it is raining like fun.

I am quite concerned by the number of crime sheets filled in lately, in dealing with the men I give them as fair a deal as I can, erring frequently on the side of leniency.

IX

33
Entry.26:
Went down to the Osterley this morning had a yarn with the Assist Purser she is a beautiful boat but of course like all boats there are the usual smells. Tomorrow she leaves for Brisbane €” our papers are compete.

It rained all day. I lectured No 1 & 2 sections on Bombs this afternoon.

At dinner time today trouble occurred with Don Ohagan. he has a quick temper & told Sgt Dunn that he would pour the over him. I laughed when I heard of it. Paraded OHagan & had a quiet talk with him he is allright & a good man but his temper gets the better of him at times.

Stayed in tonight & wrote letters, Braddock brought in the box for my sword. I intend to send it home. Had a bad report concerning Don Todd. He is evidently not playing the game.
Entry.27:
Rained again today. Gell gave a lecture on Mathematics to about 6 men the rest were hanging about in the YMCA shed. OHagan came into the office & apologised for the trouble of yesterday.

X

 

35
Entry.29: Entirely engaged in getting my unit ready for sailing on the
Entry.30: I went up to the Harringtons for tea & stayed the night, they were awfully kind to me. Sunday I wandered down to the O'Reilly's. O'Reilly enlisted & I was able to give him some assistance re the artillery.
Entry.31: Had a Theatre evening & we went to "Fair and Warmer" a comical farce. I took Misses Harrington & Kirkwood & enjoyed myself. We did not parade to the theatre but merely went down individually.
Entry.32: I went along to North Sydney to the Waterhouses. Capt Waterhouse is coming home wounded. Mrs Waterhouse is awfully excited.
Entry.33:
Went along to the Moore's for dinner. I must say that although these folks are awfully proper they have always given me a good time. I laughed over the races we had to catch the boat & train etc. 

X1

Miss C Moore is particularly proper but hasn't caught a husband yet.

 

37
Entry.34:
Our Review, The General said a few words to me as he came along our march past was good, after the march past in Column we marched past in column of route. I saw Dr Susie it was awully good of her to come along.

Miss Harrington & Kirkwood came to mess & we had quite a silly evening, I arrived home quite late.

The Major & Mr had a few nice words to say after mess to which I replied briefly

 congratulated us on our march past.

I dismissed our men about 5.20pm €” they were free to go home with their friends.

Advance party left at 12.40 pm under Lieut Black was absent.
Entry.35:
Left for Boat Osterley at 7.50. I Said good bye to many of the officers & the men

XII

39

cheered us as we marched away it felt jolly hard. Friends of the men were waiting for us at the gate & our column some became a mixture of all sorts. 'B' Co became some company 4 deep in places. The band played all sorts of stuff & had to slow down considerably Poor old Gibbons has lost a considerable amount of swett since he tackled carrying the flag it opened up beautifully to the light breeze

We stoped at the bottom of Macquarie St to give the men a chance to say good bye & it was only with considerable trouble that we got it going again. The column disappeared entirely when we got to the gates of the wharf. it absolutely disolved, however they collected on the wharf allright. Only 2 old stagers were absent & I was rather amused to see Turner €”a waiting man right away up the rigging

Among the crowd I saw Mr Sawkins & as they streamed on the wharf I saw Dr Susie fight her way to the port & she waved until we were out of sight.

Sydney Harbour looked beautiful & we steamed right out to sea.

XIII

41

The men soon settled down & shortly we had dinner under way. It was remarkably smooth & very little sickness occurred

The chaps took to it well, we apppointed permanent mess orderlies & I am considering making L.Cpl Swan permanent mess or Troop Deck Sergeant.

I had a very bad head & was a little sick I suppose it must have been the worry getting the men away

Gell was a bit of a nuisance & would cruise around & act the darned gentleman. I gave him a good solid bump he needs them occasionally.

Betty Marsh of Macquarie House sent me some cigarettes & gave me quite a good send off. I met her at the top of the Bulli Pass & she recognised my photo in one of the weeklies. Cpl Hodgson a friend of hers enlightened her regarding my name she is a jolly good sport

I happened to sit down to dinner against Mr of Adelaide. Stewart Metters is his son

 

VIV

 

43
Entry.36:
There are quite a number of passengers aboard although I have not spoken to them yet, we have a great deal of work fixing up our men €” being quite smooth it enables us to do this easily. The sea is lovely & calm & no cases of sickness have occurred. We passed Wilsons Promontory and looked very beautiful it is the most southerly point in Australia.

The treees have been ring barked & appear quite dead.. The hills rise right out of the sea, we passed many islands one near the lighthouse is peculiar, being alll eaten out by wind action, I took a photo of the lighthouse.

A little boxing was indulged in, one spar between OHagan & Smith was exceedingly amusing.

Divine Service was conducted during the morning our Engineer Band played,the service was very dead & dull

The Col roared respecting a criticism of his control by the subalterns €” quite right too

XV

45
Entry.37:
Arrived in Melb about 6am really I had so much to do that we were here before I knew

Leave was granted to all men not on duty. Turner gave a little trouble, he paraded to the ships adjutant & got leave

We had to provide a town Piquet of one officer & men took No 1 section, Deacon had control

I went into the city cruised around a little then went out to Box Hill & met Mr & Mr Fraser & Mrs Oakley they were awfully good

At night I went out to the & had dinner with them. a good old yarn & I got the surprise of my life when Dorothy kissed me so I kissed Marjorie & hopped into the moving train €” eh! what!

Arrived at the Osterley about 11.30pm

XVI

47
Entry.38:
Leave again today, let most of my men go, whilst on inspection I received a note from Iris & obtaining leave I joined her. Got my men ashore & went down to Queenscliffe in the boat it was simply ripping Milly Whitworth was there & they saw me off. I arrived back in Melb about 7pm

Had a yarn with Turner I think he will give less trouble in future

Met Mr & Mrs Read, Dr Susies Friend aboard they are going to Adelaide, Dr Susan wrote to Mrs Read stating that she had written to my Mother.
Entry.39:
Paraded the men at 6.30am €” about 9am an additional contingent came alongside €” artillery

The Governor General inspected the boat. I was presented to him & he spoke to my men

James Whitworth came to see me off. Col Wilkenson came aboard €” we left about 12 noon

XVII

49

The wharf presented the usual brilliant scene. James got under a purple umbrella & I picked him out for quite a long time. Tugs assisted to get us out. After 2 hours steaming along the strange channel in Port Phillip we got to the Rip it is a strange place eddies everwhere. A Bush fire was passed some fire too near Sorrento. The forts are strange low places. I saw my cousins at Queenscliff thro glassed it was awfully kind of them to look out for me.
Entry.40: Nothing especial occured sometimes low hills would show up beyond the horizon. The Col gave me leave in Adelaide.
Entry.41:
Arrived in Adelaide about 6am. touched the wharf as I was getting up. Went on Parade & afterwards made a pass out for myself & caught the 7.30 train for Town. It just seemed to crawl along & I reckoned it was absolutely the slowest train in Australia. Hadnt time to ring up Mrs Scott so a Porter did it for me telling her I was coming for breakfast

XVIII

 

51

She had breakfast ready & it did taste nice. The weather was simply beautiful & it was good to be ashore. I took snaps of Mr & Mrs Scott to give to Ron.

After a hurried few minutes I wandered off to see Mr & Mrs Rooney & afterwards I was just in time to catch "Mum" & they were just leaving to go to the Outer Harbor. we went into the house to yarn to Miss Jos it was quite like old times. We went to catch the 10.30 am for the Outer Harbor it was detained on a/c of the mail.

Met Freda & Margaret Miss Wright, Mr & Mrs Scott, Mrs Mrs Bailey Mr Mrs & Miss Chapel. Dr Phoebe is travelling aboard. Mr Mrs Taylor of the South Aust Harbors Board, Miss Taylor is travelling by the Osterley.

All went down by the same train, & after a glance at the boat we went to the rear of the station & saw our men also saw Gibbons with our flag €” it interested my party a whole lot to see it Mum & Freda were quite enthusiastic.

After seeing the men go aboard we went after some tea people were not allowed aboard

XIX

 

53
Entry.42:
I dug up a tea Kiosk, & also made my own tea it was quite a merry party

The Stones & Mr came to the wharf, & filled my pockets

 Mum & the rest of them filled my arms €” it took all the breath out of one of my sergeants

 We had streamers out & at last they broke. I rapidly pulled mine in to get the end Mum waved to the end, it was good of her to wait she must have been tired €” my word I had a good time looking into all my packages €” it took some time too

 We ran into bad weather in the Bight

 Saturday 17

 Delightfully sea sick

 Sunday 18

 Sea sick, a miserable roll & pitch
Entry.43:
Met Dr P Chapel aboard after a days sea sickness didn't know her. showed

XX

55

up about noon & we coasted the remainder of the day €” heavy seas. Col stated that we would strike Freemantle, tomorrow about 2 pm
Entry.44: Arrived at Freemantle & troops were given leave till 8 PM. I went into the city & saw Mr & Mrs , had tea with them. I like Perth very much it appears to be a city with a future, They have some of those stepless cars there & I was much interested. I returned to the boat at 8 pm. Had a good deal of trouble with drunks being Orderly Off. The quacks used the stomach bump on one or two,
Entry.45: Left Freemantle about 5 pm. met Deacons people. Was Orderly Officer & organised the disembarkation of troops 1300 went ashore in 30 mins down one gangway & reembarked in 35 mins. Mrs came down before we sailed The Encounter was in Port. Freemantle is a funny little place & the harbor is awkward being very small. They are deepening it & have an interesting rock boring plant.
Entry.48: Tried boat drill. had an alarm during the afternoon. it took 20 mins to get men with belts to their stations our men fell in quickly. The southern constellation looked beautiful tonight Venus was simply charmnig.
Entry.49:
Inspection men fell in dressed. of course some couldn't find their gear etc. It rained a little & the inspection was not a success. Col Heritage rousted on the Orderly Off. for not having things ready. The church service was not a success, so I and a few engineers made our way to the 1st Saloon to join in the captains service. It is a moving service, church at sea & one feels how much we are dependant on our creator. The Capt conducted the service & it did one good to note how heartily he entered into the spirit of it. I felt much refreshed. Have chummed up with a chap called Boyce he is awfully decent & quite above the ordinary. I am glad to know him.

XXII

59
Entry.50: Nothing of any import has occurred since my last entry. Today has been extremely calm. the boxing contest commenced today. Smith our warrior? was hopelessly knocked out. We saw a school of small whales, rather interesting. A pleasant concert came off this evening.
Entry.51: One of our engineers Downey won his round of boxing. Sea nice & calm
Entry.52: Boat drill during the afternoon. Boxing very neat? & good Smith was hopelessly knocked out again. O'Hagan, Turner & Farrell won their bouts, I played "Let us have peace" for Mrs during the evening. We are now quite used to the sea.
Entry.53:
The P.M.O. got us together and gave us certain instructions regarding Durban & the restrictions imposed upon our men

 Received acquittance rolls, to be filled in before payment is made to the men. £1 is to be given to each man & £5 to the officers.

XXIII

61
Entry.54:
Arrived about 8 am at Durban. A Pilot came out & took us in. there was a considerable roll on, & he climbed up a rope

 They are buiilding a breakwater, huge concrete blocks are strewn about, evidently they handle them with a mammoth crane the entrance is extremely narrow & we entered between two walls, there is a light house €” on the starboard beam €” on a high bluff. The Harbor opens out & we berthed at a magnificent wharf. Kaffirs, Zuloes, etc. were there & we were much interested in them. We fell in at 9.30 am as usual but there was nothing doing. We received Orders during the morning & briefly they were as follows

(i) Municipal institutions & trams free till 10 pm.

(ii) All Hotel Bars are out of bounds

(iii) After the ranks march we would be dismissed at the Town Hall untill 10 pm, or alternately march back to the boat at 11 pm falling in at the Town Hall at 10.45

 We fell in at 1.30 pm

XXIV

63

marched to Town Hall, formed up in front of it & dismissed independently €” the procession was quite imposing. I dismissed the Engineers & with the officers cruised around the city in trams & Rickshaw €” very interesting €” The rickshaw boys are truly adorned feathers horns & chalked legs, awfullly athletic in build but we are told that they "founder" or contract consumption within 2 to 3 years, usually however they pull out in time, retire to the Kraals or villages & buy wives & cattle.

 During the evening we called at the Hotel Royal €” truly oriental, the waiters are black, indians I think. We talked with officers from German East Africa, they spoke of the Campaign. wished us luck but remarked that they were happy not to be coming with us. they preferred the East & the fevers

 I purchased P.Cs & a set of pipes, Boar Tobacco etc.

 The Town Hall with the gardens in front is one of the most impressive buildings I have seen. I like Durban, the spirit prevailing

XXV

65

is remarkable €” there is none of the "Go slow" policy one sees in Australia
Entry.55:
1917

 It was raining heavily this morning. so our men were not able to go on swimming parade, after 9.30 the men were permitted to stand easy & the kaffirs ashore provided considerable amusement. They were coaling the boat all night €” wages 3/-, the chief engineer told me that they did more work in 2 hrs than did the wharfies the whole of the time ^we were in Freemantle. he reckoned the workmen of Australia were awful. The men (natives) are well built men & were apparently? controlled by native policemen who carried heavy sticks which they applied vigorously to the bare skins of the kaffirs our men enjoyed it & would throw money among them just to disorganise things

 At 1.30 pm we were taken ashore for a route march €” to the beach. Saw a number of native married women. they carry the hair in a huge t??? on the back of the head.

 Returned to boat at 4 pm & got men aboard.

 A man of war (Hyacynth) came in. A few days ago a huge

XXVI

67

boat was moved outside Capetown & in Durban Harbor we saw the Sweedish boat supposed to have been implicated in laying mines.

 A huge Hospital ship the Oxfordshire came in

 There is also a huge German ship in Port, been here since the beginning of the war. Her engines are damaged by explosives.

 Had great sport with the natives, they danced some of their dances, & when money was thrown over they scrambled in the muddy water for it, a real scrimmage sometimes our chaps would heave a bucket full of water over them. The natives are awfully good tempered & did not fight for the coins. I really laughed heartily over their fun

 About 6 pm we left the wharf & immediately we were followed by a cruiser €” we saluted her & in the half light she returned it. Astern we can see the rapidly fading lights of Durban whilst ahead is a little light guiding us on. All lights are out on our steamer €” We enter the danger zone.

XXVII

69

 Our Col went off a treat to the Engineer & Field Artillery NCOs & Officers because somebody called out to him when he was going ashore we imagine he must have been mistaken because our men shouted out frequently to the natives.
Entry.56:
We awakened this morning to see over the horizon dimly the coast of Africa, ahead is our escort later in the day a mist blotted the coast from view. read some of the morse signals from the cruiser

 Took over Orderly Officer duties at 6.30 pm relieved Mr Kune

 Washing parade for our men this afternoon. after this we are cut down to the field allowance regarding water of 1 gall per man per day.

 The troop decks are awful places to sleep in, absolutely ??????? I visited all parts of the ship during my tour of duty
Entry.57:
Over took an Hospital Ship during the day €” evidently going to Capetown she was called the Delta. the men lined the rails & gave them a cheer

XXVIII

71
Entry.58:
Awakened to the fact that we were in sight of Table Mountain. Our escort had disappeared during the night the 12 apostles were quite plain. a cold wind was blowing & physical jerks became physical pain. Tugs came out & we entered the harbor €” a miserable small place. The entrance is very narrow The H.M.S. Kent was in Port also the Himalyia a armed merchant man. The Wiltshire with Australian troops aboard gave us a great welcome they did cheer. we bumped the wharf pretty hard. Cape Town looked charming nestled as it is under Table Mountain I have seldom seen a more beautiful picture.

 At 10.30 we were permitted to go ashore €” Hotels had been closed & marched to the Gardens up the famous Government avenue. I hardly recognised Capetown. There were no Rickshaws & the natives were entirely different to those in Durban €” numerous half castes & indians they do not seem so happy either.

Great crowds lined the streets & every now & then they cheered us. . Capetown ladies had arranged stalls for visiting troops & charged 1d all round. We dismissed at the gardens.

 I tried to find Deacon but didn't see him so after lunch I wandered to the museum €” very disappointed. Native side much neglected. They have a number of stones marked by early discoveries which were awfully intersting. on the veranda are guns captured in German West Africa

 Walking thro the gardens I was pleasantly surprised to see Rhodes

XXIX

73

statue €” not very imposing in itself but the inscription is unique

 Cecil John Rhodes

 1853 - 1902

 'Your Hinterland is there'

Cape Town is suffering from lack of rain, the drinking water is very muddy

 At 2.30 I jumped on a motor bus & went round Table Mountain, the country is romantic geologically it is very old consisting chiefly of granite outcrops, many of the hills have a peculiar shape

 The road is in excellent condition convict labor being used

 I was much taken with the Dutch architecture it is rather pretty. We passed some of the Military Hospitals, & the home of Cecil Rhodes.

 I met Chaplin Bonetker? €” a surprise. he is a relation of the Perth Bonetkers? he is a real decent chap & with him I visited the Rhodes Memorial, a stiff walk through the Zoo. Energy & a remarkable work. it looks as if it had been modelled with a fist & finished off with a pick. I was held spell bound & admired its beauty, whilst in the spot I made a rough sketch & finished it later. Right in the rear is a simple bust of Rhodes & above in simple type are the words "To the spirit & life work of Cecil John Rhodes who loved & served South Africa." The statue in the center front is awfully rough, there is no finish anywhere, the bust even is extremely rough but there is "some" effect

 We had tea behind the Memorial €” afterwards walked to the tram & city

XXX

75

 We walked to the Cathedral & noting lights walked in €” the sub dean was conducting evensong. To me it seemed so far as the words were concerned just a jumble, but surrounded by a beautiful building one was constrained by the touch of reverence. The building is German Gothic €” very heavy in type & after service the subdean showed to us a remarkable book cost £1000 it contains all the names of soldiers who died in the South African War. it is locked up in a little shrine in the choir. All the names are printed by hand on lamb skin each unit separately, beautiful designs head each list, & the whole effect is one of peace. The binding is of leather €” tanned by natives of Rhodesia & around the cover are the words "There is also an unwritten memorial of their graves in the hearts of men"

 We roamed round had supper & went back to the boat - had a glance over the Wiltshire €” their men are more cramped than ours

 11.3.17

 Left the wharf & anchored in Table Bay with other transports, The Himilaya had disappeard during the night. Table Mountain looked beautiful. at 12.25 pm we weighed anchor & steamed away in line the Kent leading. The Ayrshire is dreadfully slow & soon fell behind €” had to wait for her. €” nearly collided with another boat during the night €” Calm sea

 12.3.17

 Passed a convoy €” of 6 vessels to far away to tell who they were

XXX1

 

77

 We have altered our original formation & are travelling in two lines 8 ships in all including the Kent

 19.3.17

 We have enjoyed a calm sea right from Capetown not a ripple. & it has been awfully hot, perspiration simply pours off. we expect to go to Freetown in the Congo.

 Started Bridging in real earnest today, made excellent trestle Bridges.

 Saw the Southern Cross quite clearly tonight, the further pointer was almost on the horizon, it looked charming & reminded one of home & all who are dear

 Our Convoy consists of

1 Galway Castle, Kent.

1 Echuca

2 Ajaina

2 Wiltshire
Entry.60:
Ayrshire

 The boat which does not belong to the convoy is tailing on the rear, taking advantage of our protection

 Tonight I saw for the first time the Giant Plough it reminded me of my boy? days

XXXII

79

 I also finished off the Proverbs & thoroughly enjoyed them
Entry.61:
The Kent fired at a target towed behind our boat, some of the shots were very close

 I have found much comfort by occasionally reading the prayers (Church of England) for absent friends & for those in danger in the sea, we who are crossing the "danger zone" know how dependent we are

 Tonight I enjoyed a yarn with Sister she trained at the Geelong Hospital & we discovered quite a number of mutual friends.

 Capt Hutchins threatened to parade me to the Col for not paying attention at French class. He is guilty of rudeness on more than one occasion & I would be happy if he would take the matter up.

 The sea is delightfully smooth & we must be close to the line €” its awfully hot.

 Commenced to read the famous work "Ecco Homo

I
Entry.62:
Engineer Sports commenced in Well Deck at 5.45. awfully interesting Cpl Gibbons won the scratch Pull Garvey won the rope climbing I was judge

81
Entry.63:
Spent the day with No 1 Section on Bridges, constructed Single & double deck bridges, one of them carried a man weighing 12 stone

 Took on the Orderley Officer Job at 6.30 pm wandered thru troop decks at 9.45pm, the temoerature is absolutely awful I am simply bathed in perspiration candidly I don't know how the chaps sleep.

 Had a yarn with Sister Higginson, she is very talkative this saves me the worry of finding something to yarn about

 We crossed the line at 10 am this morning

 The sea continues to be calm €” we would almost welcome a gale

 24.3.17

 To darned hot to work so the Col gave us a holiday

 about noon we abruptly altered our course from Northerly to East

 Evidently we are making for Sierra Leone

 About 9.50 I made a glass of lime juice for Sister Gaff

2

83

wandered along the deck in pyjamas to give it to her, came out of a lighted cabin to the dark deck consequently I couldn't see so I bumped into a chair & emptied it over the YMCA sec's wife. €” went back to my cabin to finish off laughing

 Sunday 25.3.17

 About noon we could detect a faint haze on the horizon. A bat visited the boat €” rather a large sized one about 14" across wings

 The convoy formed up in single file, the Kent leading we went in the 3rd followed by the Wiltshire

 The sea was awfully calm but it was difficult to see far a mist hid everything over a few miles away. about 3 pm we could see distinctly the lighthouse on Cape Sierra Leone. €” a beautifully designed building. upper storey supported by columns - palms were plentiful & that little part of the coast seemed delightful Thro glasses we could distinguish quite a number of warships cruisers & shipping Brittania, "Swiftsure" "King Alfred & the "Sutlej" also other Australian shipping one is the "Kilara"

 Approaching the coast we saw a wreck evidently recent, she had run bow onto a reef - the S.S. Fulama?

3

 

85

 Shortly the Kent turned to the right & we passed thro a huge net €” stretched right across the outlet supported by buoys. A pretty little bay lies behind the light house white people were bathing there. Inland it presents a number of high hills heavily wooded. Freetown rests at the foot of the slopes it fringes the coast & looks awfully dilapidated, houses are sheltered by the trees & in only a few cases here they built on the hill tops.

 We anchored in front of Freetown & during the next day or so I will make sketches We are taking water aboard. Natives came out in Canoes. one of them sang "Australia will be there"

 Tonight the ship is fully lighted & it is really lovely to sit outside. it is cooler than during the past few days. Don't know yet whether we can land.

 A search light is playing across the net. the war ships are signalling to each other. the lights of the town, the light of the light house can be distinguished & the whole forms a pretty combination

 The Wiltshire dropped her anchor overboard

4

87
Entry.64:
As I sit here & write I see Freetown quite clearly. the roofs are mostly of Galv iron & it looks rather a poor type of plain. Trees are interspersed with the buildings. The Barracks are by far the most prominent & the grounds in front of them are well laid out. A wireless set is close to the shore The hills in the back ground are well wooded & must be 1500 ft high one longs to climb them. A camp is situated high in the hills to the right of the city. We are not permitted to land, although the passengers have gone ashore

 The Africa came in with a convoy of 3 ships containing English troops for Mesopotamia

 The natives have canoes cut from a single tree €” they are light & neat they are selling coconuts & fruit & speak fair English

 Other Australian transports are in Harbor. Bullom is low & heavily wooded. There are 2 cruisers & 3 men of war in port & the scene is interesting

 Australian Transports called here before & painted the town red €” hence we were not permitted to land Had to be content to see the passengers go ashore I got them to get some P.Cs for me.

 Expect to be at sea when we awake tomorrow

 The natives are taught English in the schools. On the cessation of slave

5

89

traffic they were carted back from America & the West Indies & dumped in Sierra Leone Freetown is run by the natives €” on the bench are two magistrates one white & one black, the natives are a useless lot but those in the interior are pretty decent €” even though they are wild bush men. Good shooting in the interior, the Cameroons are more interesting was English Officer aboard on furlough. Game there is good. The Campaign then was difficult fighting took place in heavy bush actually resolved into pushing men into it untill something happened.

 The soldiers here are negroes 39 different languages are spoken in one company

 Sierra Leone is absolutely the most unhealthy on this part of west Africa

 A cool breeze was blowing all day but it is hot tonight
Entry.65:
My sister's birthday €” wrote to her. We steamed out of Sierra Leone at 11.30 am. the day was hot, our convoy was lead by the H.M.S Brittania a 1st Class Battleship. The Halation was high & the land quickly disappeared. we were sorry not to have seen the town. A West African Officer told us some details over the table. The sea is calm.

 A court-martial has sat twice over silly little points which could have been settled otherwise

 I took photos of the 4.7" gun aft today just as we were leaving Sierra Leone
Entry.67:
Felt the first roll since we left Cape Town.

 Saw rather a curious scene today €” a school of porpoises. they lashed their into foam. they came along side our boat frequently

 The Brittanis steamed west for Battle position. we could see the flame from the guns, & the bursts when the shells struck the water. the reports took 23 seconds to reach us & were sinister. we could only see her dimly, there was a mist.
Entry.68:
Pay day €” each man received £1 Officers £5

 Slight roll nothing to speak of

 Enjoyed a couple of games of draughts with Sister Higginson
Entry.69:
Attended a court martial as for instruction €” adjourned till Monday.

 An artist aboard saw my sketch of the lighthouse at Sierra Leone & said he was pleased with it
Entry.71: The Brittania left us to day & the Swift Sure took charge We had communion this morning & church service afterwards
Entry.72: I suddenly took a full dose of influensa & went to bed
Entry.73: Still bad with influensa No 1 Section built a suspension Bridge it worked very well
Entry.74:
Still feeling rotten. Got up during the afternoon.

 Sapper Nutt had an amusing box with Sapper Bell

 Enjoyed a game of chess with Sgt Hawkins. Slept with part of my clothes on also packed my kit in case we were . We received instructions to carry at all times our water bottle & life Belt. sounds like business.
Entry.76: Up today, it is bitter cold Sports this afternoon. usual boat & Belt Parade. censored letters during the afternoon. Will be pleased when we get to England. Chaplin Walker is absolutely disgusted regarding the return of the committee re refunding £8 for band instruments purchased by our men
Entry.77:
Easter Sunday. went to communion. & after inspection Church Service. Padre Walker gave us an excellent sermon

 During the afternoon chatted with the nurses its a grand change to talk with the women occasionally.

 Evening farewell service in the 2nd Saloon. Padre Hall spoke €” very paltry & poor. Padre Walker had a go €” excellent. Lieut Boyce was also good. I am happy I went it did me good. We are performing all sorts of antics. our convoy is going in all directions €” evidently the intention is to confuse any submarines which may be in the vicinity

 We passed quite a number of boats.

 Today is bitter cold the doctors reckon that we could not last more than a few hours if we get

9

97

submarined
Entry.78:
/1917

 Took an inventory of all our gear, equipment etc this morning it was awfully cold on the poop Deck. Padre Hennessy purchased one cornet €” jolly good sport. €” when he heard the price he dropped it & went.

 Aitchison 3rd Prize 

 Harry 
Prize
 Taylor } Eucher Tournament

 Dent? }

 We tied for second place with regard to the troop decks. got £2.10.0 which I divided up among the tables 3 Artillery Victorian

 8 Engineers

 1 A.M.C.

 Whilst hanging around the Orderly room prior to taking up Orderly Officer duties at 6.25 I was surprised to see 9 dots on the horizon they came ^up in line €” a beautiful sight by 6.55 pm they had mixed up with our convoy & coming along they used the morse lamps to pick up our boats. they are tiny little boats & in the half light we could see no one on their decks. they ride low

10

 

99

in the water & must possess a very shallow draught. they make pretty pictures cutting thro the water

 Had a great yarn with the sisters about 9.45 pm I went thro the mess decks.

 We left the rest of the convoy & are going full speed thro to England which we expect to reach to morrow evening.

 Received Orders to take blankets from the men tomorrow at 9.30 am
Entry.79:
Orderly Officer today. weather very lumpy. Boat has increased speed considerably she rolls considerably. the roll eased off during the day. we zig zagged during the day €” the little ?????? of a submarine catcher did the same. she is a little thing to take care of this big boat she rides the sea beautifully but her decks are awfully wet. the spray goes right over her. I admire the men who are engaged in this work €” the discomforts are apalling

 Towards night we started to straighten our course & at present we are going full lick. I can hear
Entry.80:
101

the engines they are all out. the best is shaking & one allmost imagines that this huge mass of inert matter realized that it was struggling to get thro. The boat appears almost to realize the danger & is throwing all its energy against the forces around, trying to get into Port.

 The Colonel at an officers PowWow stated that we were in the chops of the channel €” the most dangerous part of our journey, from now (5 pm) till we arrive in Port, the risks are grave

 We saw ^the lights of Old England immediately after dinner tonight. I can hardly express my emotions. Times when a man with some ordeal who to himself hath not said this is my own, my own my native land. ?? in almost 14 years willing exile 
in ou
 on the frontiers of our mighty empire I see again the lights of England. great search lights are playing the hazards light in casting its welcome ^message across the ocean & I thank my God that I have been brought up to this present softly across the thousands of miles of sea. Yesterday a corpse in a lifeboat floated past our ship €” a gruesome reminder of our danger €” a ship had been torpedoed, I did not realize how awful this is untill I met this incident. We are still
Entry.81:
103

in danger but I feel confident that a great Hand of Love is holding the helm & in Him, I place my implicit trust.

 Away down in the smoke room, officers are celebrating the occasion most of them are drunk & a few minutes ago I heard them singing €” to me the present is one where we should play the game straight & true. how can we hope to €” in case of accident €” give to our men the care & thought we should unless we keep our minds clear. I am grateful that these amusements (?) have no attraction for me, I do not take credit for it but rather thank God for the better influences which He has granted to me & the strength He has conferred upon me. Right thro the voyage my mind has naturally given itself over to higher thoughts. My reticence? has earned for me good friends & enemies the bitter opinion of the later has to me been a compliment €” it is a compliment to have the bad opinion of some.

 The life & work ahead is dark at present €” what lies ahead I do not know I would not like to know If it is to go "West" I go unafraid, if it is to suffer €” then I ask my Maker to give me strength €” He can do it & He will.
Entry.82:
105

Sisters Goff, Higginson & Munro have been awfully kind & I will long remember them, I was chatting with them tonight

 We expect to get into Port about 1 am €” Plymouth I understand is to be our landing place.

 Tonight my thoughts go to the folks at home, my heart is full to overflowing €” I do not regret not seeing them, they are safe amidst quiet scenes, whereas I am compelled to wander thro dangers innumerable, my humble prayer is that God will strengthen & guide me thro all

 I feel inclined to put on record my great love for a prayer, we have heard it frequently aboard

 "O Thou Who rulest the waves of the sea & hast ordered it like a highway for the nations, preserve in Thy gracious keeping all those who journey thereon. Be mindful of them in toil or danger, shield them in peril; guard their lives from sin & shame & receive them at last into Thine abiding peace & rest thro Jesus Christ - our Lord"

Amen

 Deacon burst into my cabin about 1 am & stated that we had arrived the engines have stopped running I was too sleepy to say much but I remember feeling much relieved, it is hard to feel that all our perils by sea are passed

14

107

 11.4.17

 Got up about 7.30 am awfully cold, men with emergency rations & pushed things ahead ready for disembarkation. our Destroyer was no 37 she lay about 200 yds away. Plymouth is rather a fine looking city from the sea & quite a number of destroyers were moored behind the Breakwater. The Swiftsure with destroyers came in followed by the Wiltshire & a couple of our convoy We could see Eddystone from our boat

 Commenced to disembark about 11 am & trained to Tidworth an A.I.F. camp on Salisbury Plains. it snowed & was mighty cold. I met Reg Dunn. he looks awfully well. I like England.

 At Tidworth we detrained placed our universal kits in transport the men carried Webb Equipment & sea kit it was dark, about 8 pm & the road was muddy necessitating single file passed thro woods. list column & had to wait head of column went in. It snowed & I felt like Father Xmas. Arrived in camp about 10 pm fixed up our men & had supper in Officers Mess then to bed

15

109

12.4.17

 Met Davidson €” lieut in at mess. Officers jolly good chaps. Quite accidentally dropped across Brummitt doctor in No 2 Camp. Received marching orders Drivers to go to No 4 Camp, Sappers & to go to Brightlingsea, darned sad to break up old 'B' Co Enjoyed a great yarn with the major for the 16th Field Co - just forming knew many mutual friends. The huts are comfortable, the men have stoves & sleep on a low platform allowed 4 blankets. Met many sappers whom I knew in the Depot Men went for a route march to a typical English Villiage 3 miles away

13.4.17

 the camps are dreary places just great rows of sheds holding 36 men there is a stove in them 5 lbs of coal being allowed per man to provide? light, heat & cooking

 Got up early & went into Shipton a pretty village with Hawkins.

 Drivers left us today to go to No 4 Camp Parkhouse.

 We are to leave for Brightlingsea Monday

 A colonel inspected us today roused on me for not having webb equipment on €” silly cow I didn't receive any orders he spoke a lot of rot about V.D & so on

 We were complimented on the cleanliness of our huts. best in camp

16

 

111
Entry.83:
Received orders that we do not move out till Monday the 16th

Major was on Parade this morning he roared up a Capt for standing his men at ease. Drilled our men all morning. awfully cold.

 Went into Tidworth this afternoon €” it rained like got sopping wet. Tidworth is a huge barracks miles & miles of them, purchased a few articles.

 Went on Piquet duty to a little village called Cholderton, didn't like the thought of it but was delighted afterwards after detailing the duties of my men I wandered thro the village it is the old English type & I thoroughly enjoyed the church. It has been doing duty since 1292 The carved oak door is a work of art & the exterior is early English Gothic. The carved pews & coloured windows exceeding in beauty anything I have seen. In the church yard is an ancient stone font used in the time of Oliver Cromwell. & also a stone coffin in which a man was buried in the 10th century amidst the antique & the ancient. one feels the touch of the past. The little steam & thatched cottages are simply charming, Altogether it is one of the most pleasant piquets I have ever had. In the entrance to the church is a quaint brass tablet

17

113

on it are engraved the words

"Cutbert Rives of the age of 56 yeares

He deceased the 3 day of agust anno 1594

>--------------------------------------------------------<

Come nere my firends behould and see

Suche as I am suche shall you be

As is my state within this tomb

So must you be before the dome

For all men must by Gods decree

Once taste of deth as ye se me

Wherefore in time remember deth

before you lose your vitall breth."
Entry.84:
Church Parade €” uninteresting

 About 11.30 am we left for Stonehenge passing ?????? a ????? English village of Amesbury. Stonehenge is on the rise of the downs & is impressive postcards give an excellent idea of it general appearance coming back we visited the church at Amesbury 1490 it is a good type of Early English Gothic 
with
 
a
 a strange inscriptioin is on the walls - a stone to the memory of a girl with angels & the skull & cross beams in the center

 Went to the Church at Shipton dull service, there was an especial prayer for Australia €” it was full of Australians. I was interested in the ???? English type of country farmer with whiskers under their chins received moving orders for tomorrow

18

115
Entry.85:
Got our men up at 5.30 am kits stacked & everything was ready at 7.00 Marched out at 8 am arrived Tidworth at 9.10 am & trained at 9.40 am. arrived in London about 12.10 pm. it was misty & rained we saw a bit of the Thames the dome of St Pauls & Big Ben it appeared as seen in the sketches

 It was quite a ???????? getting our men & gear across from Waterloo to Liverpool St by the various underground ??? We had time for a little lunch & caught the 2.15 train for Brightlingsea. Colchester is a quaint spot.

 Brightlingsea is a dopey? hole? we were met by Dumas & taken to the various Billets. Mine is decent.

 At mess we met all our old friends & Scott gave me a good insight into the works here.
Entry.86: Held a clothing parade? over missing gear. Not much gone raining today
Entry.87:
Commenced lectures today with Mr Lawson good lecture. it rained today

 Finished off clothing parade? there were quite a number of deficiencies?

19

117
Entry.88:
Lectures again this morning later I went to Scotts party & worked in a defence scheme mining it is part of the East Coast defences don't like work after so long away from it. we have finished with our men Got a bicycle today & intend to have some interesting runs with it

 Potatoes are very scarce, some families haven't tasted them for weeks they are also cutting down the quantity of flour, sugar cakes etc
Entry.89:
Dumas, Clark Parkinson Grey, Bryden, Davies. were notified today that they shall leave for France on the 26th Spent the day on some trenches near the Parish Church. My letters posted by my Uncle Joseph two days ago have not yet arrived

 We are warned to attend at the orderly officer tomorrow about 10.30 am to finish the papers relating to the Board of Enquiry.
Entry.90:
Had a lecture from Major Stewart this morning he's lke the barbers cat.

 Went with Ron this afternoon to St Osyth Priory & village. the

20

119

Parish Church runs back into the 12th century the columns are very beautiful the font particularly interesting. We climbed up the tower among the bells, the stair case is a piece of good work. The stained glass windows are interesting one depicts the murder of St Osyth by the Danes The Darcy Tombs are charmng examples of early English art. Received my bundle of letters from home. it was awkward reading them in the street but I simply couldn't wait till I got to my digs

 We examined an old Flour Mill designed by the monks it has many interesting mechanical devises & is really more detailed attention it was part of the chattles of the Priory & is hundreds of years old.
Entry.91: Took the Congregational Church parade excellent sermon, after the service they played the American National Anthem. Spring is coming this morning was glorious
Entry.93:
Davis, Clark & Dumas left by the 10.30 am train for London enroute for France. Dumas is a jolly fine chap I am particularly fond of him. I brought a parcel over to him from his sister - Carmen? Dumas of Mount Barker

 Grey, Parkinson Boyden left by early train Wed morning did not see them go

121

 during the afternoon I walked thro the country lanes to Thorington. the church there is lovely, on my way home across the marshes I picked a bunch of primroses their message is that Spring is comming.

 Monday 23.4.17.

 Went out during the afternoon & finished off the mine with Scott & party

 During the morning we finished off the Board of Enquiry. It has been a delightful Spring Day. one of the best
Entry.94:
Today is Anzac Day & to commemorate it we were granted a half Holiday. With Lieut Phillips I cycled to Colchester, a charming ancient city established by the Romans about 50 B.C.

 The ancient city wall built by them is the finest in England. the castle the Priory, churches, buildings & streets remind one of the past. it was a ripping ride along the country lanes, even common scenes in England posess a subtle charm. I would give a great deal to be a good sketcher.

 Applied for week end leave intending to go down to Kent to see my uncle Joseph & family.
Entry.95:
Spent most of the day on explosives €” darned dull received a huge came from NZ

22

 

123
Entry.96: Secured leave & left by the 5.30 pm train for London. Auntie Mary Ellen met me at the Station & I stayed there for the night. she was awfully kind to me & we had some great yarns
Entry.97: During the morning I went thro the Tower with Auntie & the two boys it was ripping After dinner I caught the train for Stroud & was met by cousins Irene & Winnie, Auntie & Uncle were looking out for me. it was quite an experience & exciting no name for it.
Entry.98:
Went for a walk during the morning with Winnie & Irene didn't go far too much to talk about

 Caught 4.40 pm train & arrived at Brightlingsea at 11.30
Entry.99: Commenced with Scott & Littler a shaft
Entry.101: Commenced a tension bridge at the ford.
Entry.103: Commenced building Tension Bridge down at the Ford over an artificial Gap. Gathered primroses for Scotts auntie in London
Entry.104: Working on Bridge €” am Orderly Officer today for the school - this merely involves sending in reports on work executed
Entry.105: Went with Scott & Phillips to Ipswich, a quaint old town some 50 miles away. Had lunch at the Great White Horse & saw many quaint antique places
Entry.106: Made sketches of the Parish Church at Thorrington
Entry.107: Innoculated today took a rest did not feel too good
Entry.109:
Handed in report on a reconnaissance at Alersford

 Enjoyed a good yarn with Lieut Fletcher on Concrete
Entry.111:
Left at 5.30 pm for London with Scott Sexton & Littler. By tube we went to Hyde Park fix up for rooms at the Australian Officers Club & later went out to Dr James Scotts house.

 Saturday 12

 Wandered round the City with Ron purchased trench boots from ordanance & caught the 12.45 train for Stroud. Winnie & Irene met me & we were soon at home €” went over Rochester Castle

 Sunday 13

 Went for a walk with my Cousin during the morning & later in the day with my Uncle Joseph arrived at Brightlingsea about 11.30 pm
Entry.112: Hit my thumb with an axe & had to knock off work for the day
Entry.113: Found a little hedgehog today it is such a curious creature & seemed quite tame
Entry.114:
Found a nest of little blackbirds. such a neat handful in a bramble bush, will watch them grow

129
Entry.115: Pat Johnstone turned up in camp today with a crowd of pioneers. he told me lots of news about the chaps. Poor old John Rider was killed before he got to the trenches. We went on a night stunt Pontooning with the
Entry.118: Sent home a crowd of odds & ends. Uncle Joe sent me £10
Entry.119:
Left Bghtsea at 12.10 pm for London, walked from Liverpool St to Auntie Mary Ellens. the day was awfully hot & muggy & my clothes were saturated with perspiration. Auntie dried them in meantime I wore Uncle Johns togs. Spent a few pleasant hours there during which an air raid was expected we looked for the planes but could only see our patrol

 About 11 pm Auntie & the two younger boys & Uncle John took me to the tube where I left them to catch the 11.45 pm for Manchester
Entry.120:
Arrived Manchester about 6.30 am & cruised around some of the spots I remembered. The old "Moon & seven stars" has long since vanished. Wandered over to see Cousin Sally. she lives in an awful place I knocked at the door & it was answered by a slaternly girl. the inisde is just as dirty as the outside Sally was working evidently she has given up the "business" €” if the later is worth the term €” gad its miserable

131

 I then took a tram to Moston & dug up Cousin Alice. she lives in a new little house & it was awfully clean Alice knew me in a moment. unfortunately she has been very ill & looked very pale & old in build she is stouter. it was great "Malcolm" Come in" the girls were all out so she made me some breakfast which I relished. let it go cold however talking. there was a lot of ground to cover. we chatted & chatted till about 11 am & I left to go to Auntie Miss Stones

 Arrived at Heywood St at 12.30 Mrs Flannagan opened the door. I thought it was Auntie suddenly Auntie came into the Hall my stick & kit wenet flying & I immediately attacked Auntie with a huge hug. she hasn't changed much only a little thinner, still has rosy cheeks & is quite active & speaks more slowly. Mrs Flannagan is older & has not been too well. had leg which she has to ten carefully We yarned over lots of things & everybody whilst we had lunch.

 AFter lunch I cruised round the Art Gallery & the interior of the Cathedral, the pictures are excellent I purchased a number of P.C.s for Florrie.

 Nathaniel came round after tea he looks awfully white & thin. I can give him almost 2" & he was suprised to note how big I had grown, Emily did not come because of the children so we went out to his house at Flexton. it is in the country & is awfully neat & has a little garden & clean. The kiddies are fine & look well. 3 girls I quite enjoyed them calling me 'Uncle' what oh! It was jolly hard to leave them all & I wondered if we would meet again.

 Auntie & Mrs Flannagan waited till I got home

133
Entry.121:
25/ 1917

 Arrived home or rather at camp about 3 pm after purchasing a valise at London. Major stated that he hoped to keep us here for some time
Entry.122:
Turner turned up after being AWL for 5 days - silly ass placed under close arrest & court martial to come off next Monday

 'B' Co left for the Front early this morning.

 Slept all night in my clothes had a board of Enquiry into a burnt tent late last night & thought I had to get up about 3 am.

 General McKay visited our camp today & stated they Gill & myself should be detained here for a little time darned nuisance

 received quite a number of letters this morning

 Sent a number of P.C s books etc home

 July
Entry.123:
About 10.20 am I counted 20 aeroplanes flying west over doubts regarding their nationality were soon set at rest by the bursting of shrapnel near them. rumour states that there were 30 planes but I didn't

135

we watched them thro glasses till they disappeared. they surrounded themselves with gas fumes which made them hard to distinguish I distinctly saw the fumes issuing from the machines They returned & made for the sea about an hour later one of our planes flew past whilst they were somewhere in the interior
Entry.124:
Todays papers state that they got to London allright, killed 37 wounded 141. Evidently the defences are weak & we are going to suffer for I see no reason why great fleets of those mosquitoes shouldn't come over

 Took the Methodist Ch parade this morning, enjoyed the service

 It rained all day & as we only have single tents the water is dropping all over the place. thank goodness my sleeping bag is water tight

 I sat up quite late writing letters.

 Was amused at the Sgt roaring round camp "Lights out" the chaps think it a glorious opportunity to work off a few points for what Sgt Major is loved by the men
Entry.125:
Heard today that I was to be sent over to France quite early possibly next week

137
Entry.126:
Did a few O.O. jobs for Fraser & hung about camp. Went to Mr & Mrs Low's for afternoon tea and quite enjoyed chatting Australia to them

 Received letters from home Balance sheet included, didn't quite understand one or two of the terms & wrote asking about them. Sent a great number of letters & photos home about
Entry.127: & do sincerely trust that they will arrive safely. it has occupied quite a good deal of time clearing them out, to avoid censorship I sent them letter post
Entry.128:
About 8 am heavy firing was heard from the direction of Harwich we watched the puffs of shrapnel & thro glasses I detected two planes, about 11 people were killed & a number injured

 Walked - during the evening - with Capt James around some of the quiet lanes

 Lieut Fruitrell? bached in my tent last night €” he is a jolly decent chap

 Chess is about our only diversion - my luck varies.
Entry.129: Received orders to embark at Southhampton on Monday the
Entry.130:
this is excellent for I am weary of depot life. Heard today that the February and March reinfs had arrived at Park-house Salisbury. The Major gave me permission to leave here on Thursday next

 Went to Curtis's to pack up my kit. Gell is to remain here on the instructional staff

 

139
Entry.131: Left Auntie Mary Ellens about 10 am with Gerald, & picked up my luggage at Liverpool. took it via Aunties per taxi to Waterloo, left for Southampton by the mid day, there were quite a number of officers & men leaving Arrived Southampton about 3.30 pm reported and wandered round the city. it is not at all a bad little place. we visited the churches museum etc saw charred bibles etc. at 6.30 pm reported back to the boat "Viper" a little channel craft. commenced voyage to Le Havre at 8 pm. I sat on deck for about an hour & then went below to find a spot to sleep got a wooden couch & slept tip top
Entry.132:
Arrived Le Havre about 6 am & after breakfast reported to R.T.O. our camp is about 8 miles out. a tram runs out that way. had a cruise round the city. dirty sort of place almost every window has a sign "English spoken here. the French soldiers interest me some are neat and tidy others absolutely filthy

 Reported to camp No 24 Aust General Base Details. met that famous lead 

 

1

141

"darned waster", still he I suppose is doing his job fairly well. Went into town again during the afternoon met McGowan
Entry.133:
Had chg of a party for "gas masks school" it was quite a contract to find it, & must have walked at least 3 miles out of the way, the day was wet but we managed to get it finished.

 Whilst in mess I wrote home etc.
Entry.134:
Met Thornton Hargett. didn't know him till he mentioned his name he looks fairly well & is marked P.B. (heart and lungs affected with exposure) arranged to meet him at 2 pm, we wandered thro the city & suburbs jolly good time. We were highly amused with the fight in the tramcar comming home

 Received marching orders for the line.
Entry.135:
Left camp at 8.45 am in chg of a party of Artillery. picked up at rendezvous about 1600 others marched about 8 miles to Station, hot march, here I soon had my party into trucks and about 3.30 pm we commenced. our first stop was Buchy where we got a omelet & coffee about 9.30 pm

 

2

143

It was quite a rush & race across the station yard, here I got my sleeping bag from the van & about 10 pm I spread it out on the floor & fell asleep, fortunately we only had 4 officers in our carriage.
Entry.136:
Woke up at Boloine Breakfast. Had a look at my men, they were all right. The engine driver gave them hot water for tea - made it in a biscuit tin. Arrived at Calais & watched for a little time German prisoners working (?) in the huge quarries, and along the line, The railway line is in awful condition, the bridges are of excellent design & also the retaining walls, at Hazebrouck we changed trains I marched my men to a rest camp close handy. Near the station a house had been destroyed by a shell. From here we went on to Steenwerck & enroute were entertained by some French refugees from Armentieres they had hidden in a wood when the germans passed thro, their house had been destroyed by shells & they had wandered to 8 or 9 places looking for a home, poor creatures they were

3

145

simply tired out, they spoke in French & I had only a little difficulty in understanding them, it was raining heavily & as they stepped out; I realised that I had met a new feature of the war. Shell holes were numerous in the paddocks adjoining the line.

 We left the train in the rain & marched to the rest camp, here I wished my men good luck & handed them over to the Sgt Major.
Entry.137:
Slept well, foraged around for breakfast & got it

 Reported to the R.E. dump & whilst waiting was interested in the traffic, motor lorries by the hundred General service waggons, Red Cross vans & refugees leaving their homes to seek new ones, all their worldly possessions on a hand cart, behind which trudged bravely, old women & men & occasionally in their weak way they would give a push, & sometimes an Aust waggon driver would give them a lift

 During the afternoon I wandered into Steenwerck, Shrines adorn the walls, the simple inscription "Pray for us" is a

4

147

touching appeal, away from over the low ridge come the rumble of artillery, a grim reminder of our deep necessity, The shrine at the parish church is remarkable R.C. of course, About 5 pm a horse & waggon came in €” thro the telephone Major McCormac had told me that I had been allotted to the 10
th
 & I rode out to my unit at Neuve Eglise from the low ridge I saw Ploegsteert Wood and Armentieres, & also we got a glimpse of Messines Ridge

Shortly we roode into camp my unit are in rest & the officers gave me a friendly welcome. At mess one shelter was shaken by the firing of guns. about 8 pm they got the wind up & from the camp the horizon was lit up with the flashes of artillery, an awful scene. it lasted till long after midnight but long before it stopped I had fallen asleep
Entry.138:
Quiet all day. an heavy mist & low visibility. I just cruised round camp

5

149
Entry.139:
Mists & low visibility remained in camp all day, just cruised around trying to fit myself in

8.8.17

 Nice & fine this morning. got up about 8 am & left with Sgt Strom? to visit the guns, the first 3 miles thro Neuve Eglise in direction of Messines we travelled per bike, the roads were not too bad, left our machines at a R.A.P. & travelled over old British & German trenches little left of road in a position which must have been under enemy observation when the Hun held the ridge, the enemy were shelling the right side of the road, I was much interested in the concrete dug outs the walls were at least 4 ft thick, from there we picked up the Messines Road & travelled along the left of Messines the enemy were shelling it & over head the shells were whistling gives one a peculiar turn still I kidded I didn't mind, bombs, shells, shell cases, wire, tools, equipment littered the country the road was awful & the whole of the ridge has been torn up by shells, it is impossible to conceive what it is like we travelled along the edges of shell holes for miles, a damaged tank attracted our attention, the shells had passed right thro it, & bits of machinery lie right round it. Fritz was paying his

6

151

attention transports in one line?, over would come a screech & up into the air would go odds & ends for yards around splinters would tear up the earth, Shrapnel was bursting over the ridge & poor old Messines hardly distinguishable on the landscape was getting hits

 We called at one or two batteries €” the artillery is no joke, the guns are practically in the open, only thin wire camouflage covers them, the men live in holes in the earth & have an awful time, only yesterday 4 or 5 guns were knocked out & one or two crews

 We travelled round the heap of bricks once known as the town of Messines had tea with an artillery officer behind a german dug out of concrete to an observation post, another concrete Dug out & looked over the other side of Messines Ridge, whole woods have disappeared Bethlem Farm is a heap of bricks, so is Warneton (germans hold it) comming back we examined a good german dug out it had not received any kindly attention ? a plush chair & deck chair were still in it, Another Dug out had been blown to pieces & on the right of Messines the country was chewed up awful, the road we had come by was receiving

7

153

some heavy ironfoundries? gee he was laying into it, hundreds of shells had fallen since we entered the area & to miss a lovely lot he was piling in we travelled to our bikes across country, splinters fell quite close frequently & one burst too close for comfort, into the grass we went full length just as we got to our bikes one burst a few yards away & then another god we were glad to hop on & hook? it up the road.

 We stopped at the Church army hut, here lemonade is kept for all commers, free as the wind that blows, many & many a weary soldier, tired, sad, hungry, has come in to help himself, free to all

 Away just in the rear of Messines under a ruined house, €” shelled every day with everything he can heave at it €” is the Y.M.C.A. One wants to be out here to appreciate what they mean to the men, everything is f
ree
, & I thank God that there are brave men who do it, I saw a dozen Australians enjoying a cup of tea there.
Entry.140:
155

 Over on the left the Huns were heaving stuff into Hells Wood. it is a hell too, long before the noise of the burst came we would see whole trees go up, theres not much of the wood left just a few stumps.

 Tucked away in little corners we passed lots of soldiers graves just a simple cross over head, in many cases these were broken by shell fire, they had fallen in the great Messines Stunt, one is reminded of the book in Capetown €”"There is an unwritten memorial of them engraven into the hearts of men"

 Its raining hard tonight, in my comfortable tent its quite comfortable & cosy, but I cannot help thinking of those poor chaps out on Messines Ridge, with hardly any shelter they are sticking to their posts & have stuck to them for the past 6 weeks, its awful out there.

 Somehow I am not sleeping well tonight possibly it is due to the excitement today we had some near goes, being within a few yds of 3 on the flat near Messines Neuve Eglise Road, The rumble of Artillery is constant & the flashes on the east horizon, resemble sheet lightening

9

157
Entry.141:
The Rev Arch Deacon Ward addressed the troops this morning on general topics €” awfully good

 Met Stew Metters, he is attached to the 11th Field Co & looks awfully well, it will be remembered that his Mother was at the Outer Harbor when we left & his father travelled from Sydney to Melb in the Osterley, during the evening he came thro camp & yarned for an hour or so.

 A big observation Balloon of ours came down in flames today I saw the smoke, the weather has cleared right up & Mount Kenmel stands out beautifully clear
Entry.142:
Weather good 32 balloons up, saw an aeroplane drop, Fritz himself shelling our planes & balloons, Shells dropped into Neuve Eglise killing a number of our men.

 Phillips a cousin of the Whitworths introduced himself today he is in our company.

 Ron Scott wrote telling me that Cecil Dunn had been killed at Messines, I saw lots of graves up there, they were well cared for. Commenced a letter to Mr & Mrs Scott. The atmosphere is alive

10

159

this evening with the hum of aeroplanes, they carry lights & look like moving stars, the artillery is quite.
Entry.143: Saturday, watched the bursting of shells, near our balloons fixed up arrangements for lecture on electrical detonation, one detonator exploded
Entry.144:
Reported on ranges at various points near here.

 Williams called in he is going on leave. looks pretty good says that John Ryan was only injured. Heard from Leslie Rooney these are his colours

 Fritz's butterflies were pretty heavy with bombs last night, also he shelled around our camp.
Entry.145:
Today we received orders to shift down to St Omer, the Major stated that in future we are to be shock troops.

14.8.17

 Left Neuve Eglise at 7.30 am, I cleaned up the camp & left for Ballieul at 10 am. secured seats for my men in lorries

Met Bill at Wizernes €” never cared for him much he was in the Barwon Rowing Club

 

11

161

which travelled in that direction.

 Gave men ½ hr leave in Ballieul & marched to the station

 Train left for Wizernes at 12 noon & we detrained at Wizernes near St Omer at 3 pm, Sappers unloaded train & we marched some 16 miles to our billets, it rained heavily & I was sopping whilst marching thro LumbrÃ¨s I saw some Pioneers & soon got in touch with Mulley, Murell Ramsay & others, we stopped outside the village for something to eat, I went back & had dinner with Mulley jolly good chap, Marched off again at 8.30 pm I had a water proof sheet from Mulley & this kept off the rain, Our guide missed the way twice & we had trouble with the transport, I didn't reach my billet till 2 am, a miserable show it was too, Madame got up out of bed & made some coffee €” the French can make coffee too €” which I thoroughly appreciated & then crept off to bed, was in my room - a jolly good chap too - The stench from the middens was awful I felt like choking
Entry.147:
Got up late & cruised around the country looks tip top & reminds one of England, it looked like rain, & the courtyard was metaphorically up to the eyes in mud these people have no idea of clean-liness, & chuck their refuse about anywhere. went down to the village it consists of a few scattered houses & a church, 
An old
Entry.148: Went down to a 2 pm parade €” soon dismissed. Lieut Inglis of the 5th came over today
Entry.149:
Day, Scott & Lieut Wilks came over from Arques I was glad to see my old friend we siimply enjoyed a yarn, he is not too comfortable with the unit, the older officers sling off abouf the "deep thinkers", Rode back to with them my horse was hard marched & fresh & kept me thinking.

13

165
Entry.150: Rode to LumbrÃ¨s to see Mulley & the rest of the chaps had mess with them & afterwards rode home with Strom, just a nice little cross country ride.
Entry.151:
Improving with my french Went to church parade this morning, a pretty little service under the trees.

 During the afternoon I thought over my lecture for tomorrow wrote one or two letters
Entry.152: Lectured on Electrical Detonation to the company, We have a parade ground behind our mess. The past two days we have had glorious weather & this village is awfully beautiful, its real name is Bliquin. sometimes Neille is prefaced. Had a letter from Cousin Harry. Commenced Trench with Martin
Entry.153:
A nice day - it will be excellent for the crops the villagers work in the fields early & late the present sunshine will give them a chance. Tested some of our electrical equipment during the morning & evening. Swotted French till quite late

14

167
Entry.154: I havn't seen a paper for days evidently these necessities of city life don't come along. today is "bonser" our men have this afternoon off & games have been arranged
Entry.155: Rained today men did not parade in the rain
Entry.156: Windy. took No 3 section to the farm & overhauled tool cart Mahy & Bothwick have gone thro to Boulogne I hope to take a run thro during the next few days. Wrote to May Hamilton, she has evidently had a breakdown
Entry.157: Quiet day, nice weather was orderly officer. had a letter from Les Rooney
Entry.158:
Nice service down in the village this morning. "What shall it profit a man if he gain the whole world" the 37th were on Parade, these services would be deeply impressive to a civilian, the drab uniform & the surrounding colours must make a lovely picture

15

169

27-29.8.17

 It has rained heavily during the pasat two or 3 days. The major returned on the
Entry.159: from England. he was in Brightlingsea & saw all the old chaps. the
Entry.160:
Field Co were still there

 Improved the mens messing quarters this morning & will further improve them tomorrow

 AFternoon off this afternoon it rained so I studied french

 Heard that Mr was pushing a scheme for making boats our of reinf concrete.

 Major entertained us today after lunch with yarns of his trip.

 Mahy our senior sub is an officious sort of cow at times he is almost objectionable I suppose I am a young cub & not worth noticing
Entry.161: It rained heavily all day but I rode into Devres on a bicycle on the top of the hill the wind was strong, could'nt ride against it Many New Zealanders are camped in the Valley I spoke to a few of
Entry.162:
171

them. Devres is a miserable show the church is not to bad it would be a whole lot better if they pitched 
xxxx
 those awful plaester figures into the nearest ditch, The church is of fine massive design. The streets are very dirty I had a cup of coffee at a estaminet & chatted with a french soldier from he was very tolerant to my French & quite chatty.

 The dame who kept the book shop wa astounded because I spoke a little french, brought out a bonser little kiddie whose daddy was a soldier, it gave me a kiss I hadn't enough small change to pay for the PCs & the lady would not charge a note for me saying that I was quite welcome to the PCs, returned thro Lottinghien, the wind helped me home. Teased my little amoureuse when I got home about my new little amoureuse at Devres, she got quite worried over it but as I had some chocolate & a little book for her the atmosphere soon cleared, we are going to be married aprÃ¨s la guerre & have a farm with some pigs & a

17

173
