big cow & also a little one. I often smile over it, but it is tip top to have something to take ones mind away from the war
Entry.163:
Received orders to shift today, Engineer Transport was inspected along with divisional Transport at Senlecques Went over to our new billet this afternoon It is on an isolated spot miles away from anywhere our men will have a cleaner billet which is something to be thankful for.

 I feel quite sorry to leave my present billet the people have been awfully good to me & from them I have learned a good deal of french

 There was a company concert at the mess tonight it was not too bad

 Mr Williams our other Lieut returned today, he is affiable & friendly. The weahter today has been excellent, the sun shined for a change & the mud dried up a little
Entry.164: Marched to new billets this morning €” Galopin €” arrived about noon, commenced to make ourselves comfortable & soon had things going pretty fair. The farmer is always drunk & mumbles out a sort of drawly french which I cannot understand. The men made a thorough cleanout of the barns
Entry.165:
175

cook house, mess tent etc soon popped up. my room stinks awful so I heaved out a lot of the lumber It rained during the night & some of our chaps had to clear out
Entry.166:
Mess up with orders, we marched to Beaumont with full kit & soundly cursed the powers what are

 Marched back & during the afternoon made things more ship shape. I am eating the same food as the men, it is fairly good & wholesome. We are cleaning up the transport. Bothwick is with me in chg of No 4 Section, A Divisional route march takes place on Tuesday next. Met our C.R.E.

 Marched in fighting order about 7 miles today I laughed at the strangest remarks of Sapper Stone he is the section wit. We bathed in the creek at Blequin, our transport looks tip top. Orders came thro that we are to build the Divisional Clink
Entry.167: During the past two days things have been pretty busy preparing for the route march tomorrow
Entry.168:
177

 The route is approx 14 ½ miles, & runs approx round this ridge, the men have cleaned up their equipment & it looks very well I reckon my section is the best in the bunch. We had an inspection by Major McCormack on the St Omer Desvres Road this afternoon One is not impressed by the major hes not the big man he ought to be, his remarks were lame & weak. Here I am playing second fiddle to Bothwick he is senior officer Today the weather has been glorious.

 Yesterday I made a couple of sketched for home, one was not too bad of the farm yard here, sat on an old waggon whilslt doing it. Posted them home this morning

 Amps one of the chaps is not too well somehow I fancy he has a weak sort of constitution.

 The fruit in the orchard is not yet ripe, tried some apples & wallnuts today, the farmer is a real decent fellow & helps us quite a lot, Our camp is fine I miss the french people at Blequin very much.

 Mahy entertained me a couple of days ago & informed me that my methods of treating the men was absolutely rotten, its pleasant to find someone who gives you a candid statement, he was so drunk that he fell off his horse going home, this of itself is sufficient to discredit his remarks. We all have our ideoseyncrosies & our own methods & some of us would'nt swapp either

20

179
Entry.169:
The day is tip top for the route march, sunny without being hot Left Galopin about 10.15 am for the rendezvous met the rest of the company & marched across the ridge, I am quite consious that the packs were not filled with issue gear, they looked neat that was the main point, when walking over No 4 Section Billet after we got home I saw the men pulling straw out of the packs, could'nt help laughing. it's no joke carrying 70 lbs of equipment just for show. & it is possible that I encouraged my men to carry as light a pack as they could.

 We passed the saluting t about 3 pm, Generals Godley, Monash & Brig Gen McNicholl

 Arrived home about 6 pm I rode a mangy old mare, but she saved me the trouble of walking so I feel quite fresh, the men marched well particularly my own section.

 A good dinner awaited us unfortunately there was no bread, we had a stew with army biscuits, apples & rice, €” the apples I feel satisfied were borrowed €” I saved some of the latter for supper.

 Women were ploughing in the fields, they receive 40 francs per month & for this they work more hard than any of our workmen, for tea they receive jam & bread & wine, the bread is heavy & dark possibly it is the black bread of which I have often heard

 

21

181
Entry.170:
Marched over to Fauquem-bergues to look over the line selected should the Germans break thro from Galopin the distance would be approx 10 miles

 Met the Officers they gave us a good time.
Entry.171: Bivouaced last night in a wood & marched back today.
Entry.172:
Gray my corporal went on holiday to England, Strom has gone to school in Burnell is now sergeant.

 Today we had a of Engineers 9th. 10th.
Entry.173: at Drionville about 4 miles away €” good stunt particularly the section movements in the hollow square.
Entry.174: Rained heavily during the night & this morning €” nothing special doing. Lectured on concrete its construction & manufacture, rather enjoyed it.
Entry.175:
Gave the Capt a smack for riding on this , he paraded me before the Major & I was practically told to be a good boy

 Huge review by Haig near Drionville, extremely impressive Met Matters & Burgess of Adelaide about 15000 troops on Parade Haig inspected accompanied by Monash the General of our division Engineers were complimented

183

 Burnell my sgt has to go to a Brigade school today

 I go to Gas School on Sunday next €” I am sorry over it but they say it is good
Entry.176:
Cruised over to Halte D'ouvre via Blequin & called on Harry Symonds an old friend of mine in South Aust, he looks yip yop, Reported at the Gas School but was ordered to report back to my unit as orders had come thro to move to the lines, rather pleased.

 Called on the C.R.E he was about to leave for the 10th & he asked if I would like to ride with him, giving my bike to the batman I hopped up on the best bit of horse flesh I have yet ridden, we cut across country & enjoyed some exciting gallops, the sunken roads are dangerous & I nearly came off once. it was "bonser"

 The Colonel has no fancy notions & does not shove on military airs to we godforsaken
Entry.177:
lieuts as a matter of fact it has been the best afternoon I have had since comming to France, we had tea together

185

& later I left for Galopin. We expect to move on Wednesday.
Entry.178:
Commenced to pack up & get ready, it was lovely so this morning we gave the men a swim in the creek at Blequin, was late returning this messed up the afternoon parade, Bothwick an uncouth colt was initiated into the Kelly Gang No 4 Section, Williams is crook something wrong with the Kidneys.

 Received orders at 10.30 pm to move tomorrow, Parade to be at 7 am There is a marked diff in the way the Capt treated me today they're sick sorts, & the ride with the Colonel which I had makes them follow just as though the had a ring through the nose as Teague told me on Saturday get in with the Colonel the others will come into line, its true to, I laughed to myself today when Mahy referred to my trip to the school & Divis Headquarters but I did'nt let on about the ride with the Colonel, I knew that he knew of it & would be expecting me to crow but I did'nt
Entry.180:
Nothing much doing except long marches I had chg of 100 infantry who gave me a solid time they are selected specimens from their battalions of course they push off their worst characters some fell out & I lost about 8 or 9 they simply wouldnt keep up, so I ceased to worry over them, depended on a roll call absentees will have to be dealt with as they come up the second day of the march they strung out & lagged behind all along the road, only one Sapper fell out & he joined us later

187
Entry.181: Left our comfortable quarters near Cassells & our men marched 20 miles to Ypers, It was jolly hard marching the air was filled with dust & the traffic along the Poperinge - Ypers road was tremendous. An aeroplane dropped bombs alongside, a search light picked her out she looked like a silver fish in the sky. Arrived at our new billets about 10 pm. The house & buildings are all destroyed €” not a whole house within miles of Ypers €” an evidence of Hun outrage
Entry.182:
Cruised round a little saw the Cathedral & Cloth Hall, it is a pitiful sight to see such glorious buildings destroyed. Went into the city wall the face is pitted with shell fire later we went out along the Menin Road & over the country recently taken by our men, the country is torn up with shells similar to Messines, but the bruised strip is much wider, Dead germans & our men lay around & some of the sights were shocking Bones sticking out of boots etc. A german machine gun possie had received a direct hit & was full of dead germans. There are many strong concrete emplacements Square Farm, Borry Farm, Bremens 

189

Lowe Farm, Snitchells Farm, quite close together & must have been hot spots Bothwick had a job last night emptying Borry Farm of dead germans. A couple of dead aeroplanes lay around I sent a bit of one home to Florry, Dead tanks were numerous I saw about 10 quite close to 'K' track.
Entry.183:
Heard that Bothwick & a sergeant had been wounded so came back into camp €” had to take on his work The major took me round to the Pioneer camp €” met Capt Stephenson who showed us a lovely dud "aerial Torpedo" & met Capt Keating with whom I had to make a reconnaissance of "K" Track. left Monin Gate Ypres at 5.30 pm walked out to "Sq Farm" where Brigade Hqts will be for the Stunt saw General €” interesting & left there about 10 pm going along "G" track & later K track they meet at Lowe Farm

 Here we saw some Pioneers at work, we passed a dead tank, alongside it lay an Australian, he looked quite at peace & as though cut out of wax, further on we passed the old Fritz strong pts am becomming quite used to the smells of the battle field, they're pretty solid & we saw lots of dead lying about

191

Past Bremens Redoubt we sink into the hollow where are erected a number of bridges over the creek. Verry lights were numerous €” these of course meant sinking down into Mother Earth, a Fritz was sweeping the track with a machine gun €” the bullets have a peculiar whistle. dead men lay in shell holes so quiet & still, Crossing the bridges which had been "stonkered" we climbed up the other side old Fritz kept going fairly solid with his gun €” the cow, a party comming back for rations upset his equilibrium & he started to lobb shells over a 'dud' dropped into the next shell hole to mine, he has this creek well & truly marked & he can lamb it hard in, These bridges form the 
key
 to our position tonight, Finch a chum of mine is looking after them

 Comming back to the creek we passed a couple of men snipped by our "cobber" with the gun €” one was a stretcher bearer & lay like a man who has met the future as a man & a soldier. The other man was so natural we shook him to see if he was only sleeping.
Entry.184:
Went out this afternoon to the dump BAVARIA FARM saw a wounded tank crawling over the ridge walked over &

 

193

sat on it. a shell had hit it on the nose. examined a fallen aeroplane & sent a bit of it home €” it was not far from 'Bavaria Farm'

 Fritz got a bit nasty during the afternoon & heaved some stuff over €” its really surprising how close he gets to doing something serious & how seldom he gets anything at all

 The roads are full of traffic €” all kinds 

 I laughed last night a man rushed along the road €” "I;ve got a blighty" €” one thro the arm he seemed quite happy about it

 Last night whilst out I witnessed a practice barrage €” some stunt.
Entry.185:
Nothing doing hung about all day, Sgt Furness was killed whilst consolidating with Lt Shaw in new Front line

 Took a run over to see the prisoners, they look war weary & sick & tired. this morning they commenced to roll in ¾ hr after our barrage opened at the compounds Germans were searched & immediately forwarded on. In the

195

field Germans were used to carry stretchers they did the work willingly

 At no point did they show any real fight our barrage takes all the fight out of them, actually they streamed from their concrete dug-outs as our men approached, with arms held upwards, our men are keen hunters for souvenirs & would run thro their pockets etc but never did I hear of any real cruelty.

 At the A.M.C. i visited Vincent one of old "B" Co €” he had a neat Blighty but was quite contented. The scenes here were awful Blood, blood, blood, everywhere I felt sick & cleared out Amos, Booker - shell shock
Entry.186: Received instructions to go out to the Lowe Farm Road to make a reconnaissance, Burgess a S.A. chap was out there, Rain had fallen during the night & the Zonnerbeck Road was in the devil of a mess, the traffic was blocked by some motor lorries went out with Capt Cox of the
Entry.187:
I have never witnessed such awful sights "C'est la guerre" Wounded men owing to the block of traffic were lying in the rain, dead men were numerous alongside the road but those

197

who had been trampled in the mud were greater "C'est la guerre" but oh! how awful The country north of Lowe farm is swampy & is literally solid wth partially decomposed human remains the smell is terrific I had difficulty in finding a spot where I could sit without sitting on a corpse, Germans Highlanders, & English lie close together, two Germans are locked in each others arms near Beck Farm €” the scene is beyond description €” it used to be a peaceful little brook but today it is a morass where many a brave man has found his grave €” The smell goes with me everywhere it is in the water I drink, in the food I eat, in the air I breath, on my hands, boots clothes & vainly I try to forget.

 (Noon) Walking down Zonnebeck Road I saw a couple of dead horses & a man €” Capt Cox said "he is one of your chaps Stanley" €” he was lying right in the muddy road, a few more minutes & he would have gone for ever, he had died instantly

199

I sent in a message to the Major & we placed him on a bit of track a little on one side €” A German shell had burst a few feet away

 All afternoon he was shelling lobbed a few near Bavaria Farm & Lowe Farm, he shelled our planes rather clever at this latter

 My party arrived about 6 pm under Sgt Thomas €” gave them a task & then stated they could go home, one job included part of the morass 60 yds of road for 55 men, the intention is to use it for artillery for the next stunt.

 8 pm S.O.S. signals were going up as we came home €” gad! the artillery did lick in the shells, it was magnificent & horrible €” the scenes where those shells were bursting must have bee terrible. here we see miles of country without a single blade of grass tree or house €” a strip of desolation & a rendez vous if death

201
Entry.188:
Started out this morning at 7 am to fix track across from "Van Isackere's" Farm to support line €” a rotten job because it is under enemy observation & included a bridge across a morass. I had Cpl Grey & an infantry Party on the bridge, Burkett & party went ahead pegging down a tape to the support line €” this latter they quickly carried out. We were shelled whilst working on the bridge shrapnel & high explosive, fortunately there was any amount of timber about, I used some from a broken bridge a few feet away.

 From Bremen Redoubt to the road was carried out by Shaw, an attached infantry officer

 After fighting our way back to Ypres thro the mud, tired out & weary I received orders to go out & shift a portion of the track near 197th Brigade Hdqrs €” so pushed off again with 6 sappers past Square Farm to Lowe Farm, Fritz was shelling Lowe Farm & incidentally a Lancashire Brigade close handy. It was raining heavily & a cold wind blowing, the Manchesters

203

were crawling out of their holes & assembling for the approach march, poor fellows, later I watched them plugging up to the lines, the road was awful, holes full of mud, a sea of mud every where, walking along, one would suddenly go down up to the thighs, & we pulled one little Tommy out of a hole €” centre of the road he was about done & out to it. There was a block of waggons mules, tractors, limbers & men 5 miles in length.

 My job was to turn a track to prevent the 197th & 198th Brigades getting mixed, Picking up some Pioneers at Lowe Farm we carried duck boards picks & shovels & tape, pushing thro the mud we got to the job & collecting the men I explained to them what was required they worked like Trojans, in the slush rain & biting wind, they plugged right in & that bit of track saved the night. gad: these men were wonderful.

 I watched a good portion of the column go past & then made for home wet cold & weary but happy & contented €” 5 mile walk

205
Entry.189:
Offensive so far entirely successful we pushed on to 700 yds this side of Paeschendaele, The men rested all night on a line between Berlin Wood & Hamburg. The "approach march" was terrible, men would fall into shell holes & owing to the mud would be unable to get out, some of them were drowned. The night was bitter cold they had only great coats, it is marvalous that seary ^and war sick men should be able to carry the positions.

 I watched the prisoners comming in today, they are pale & white & look tired out, the Australians were cutting off their buttons €” Heard that Scott had been hurt in the thigh
Entry.190:
Received instructions to go up to the new front line & to lay a tape to Haslen €” went with Cpl Stone & & trotted from Ypers past Square Farm & old K track to Bremen Redoubt passed lots of wounded returning, in many cases each was helping the other along, the scenes were painful, from Van Isackeres to Hamburg Farm I was forced to the opinion that something had gone wrong Men were roaming on the line at Abraham Heights finding the Major in control I asked him why he permitted

207

it for Fritz would surely "stonker" them €” later he did too, gave them a frightful time €” Men lay around in Abraham Heights frightfully mauled & the officers seemed to have lost all control seemed dazed & did'nt know anything, they could give me no information beyond this that they had had an awful time, near Hamburg I saw our old "jumping off" tape & the english troops were sheltering in a rotten trench over the boot tops in mud & making absolutely no effort to improve conditions a sniper was playing hamlet & this went warily.

 Out a little way was an old Bosch strong point or pill box & out to this I crawled €” thro a morass, it was raining wounded men were groaning & a few feet ahead commenced a long line of dead & dying €” hundreds of them the Sgt Major stated that all efforts to bring men in were frustrated by Snipers & I saw some awful sights - despite favourable reports (?) the brigade had been cut up dreadfully. I tried to up the men & to get them to do something to help themselves €” no good, they

209

were simply stupified & absolutely shaken in spirit, the pill box was full of dead Bosch & I wished them to clear these out & to make the wounded more comfortable €” not a move.

 After making enquiries I was fully decided that the attack had been a "beackle" & that the English had not advanced more than a few yards

 Called in at the Artillery comming home & gave them my version of the position, later I called at CRE & gave it to them they would hardly believe me but later evidence proved me to be correct. The General gave me lunch good one too €” grouse ham & wine

 The officers ^English are 
absolutely
 incompetant 
absolutely
. rotten failure & costly too in men they must have lost thousands the General said he only lost 2000 damned lie there were hundreds unaccounted for, they couldnt get to them.

 They commenced burying dead this morning, & were covering up one man when they saw him move so they took him out again & put him on a stretcher

 The sounded lay out there for hours & hours, they were moving

211

in "No Mans" land €” poor cows, but I suppose "it is the war"

 Tomorrow I have a 
dangerous
 job & move away to the line forward at 3 am

 On the approach march they ^(the Manchesters) carried 
full
 kits! awful, this after they had rested 2 nights & days in the open, wet & cold.

11.10.17

 Picked up an halfpenny in "No Mans Land" yesterday. I remarked at the time that it would bring me luck, With Cpl Cain, Stone, an officer Rutteridge, I moved out at 3 am & arrived at the front line about 6.30, the Manchesters were still limping out, I gave water to quite a number, dug 2 out of the mud they were too exhausted & weary, walking along I heard a voice "dig me out" looking round I saw nothing but the voice continued so we cruised round untill we discovered that it emanated from under a tin hat, he was covered right over €” his mates were passing they were too weary to even notice him €” Australians had to dig him out

 Walking on I wandered thro Hamburg Farm to a sunken road, tried to get information respecting our front line €” nothing doing, nobody knew anything. seeing a dug out €” I was

213

there yesterday. so I crawled over €” did'nt walk, no darned fear, snipers were to handy. seeing an officer Mr Josephs of the 42nd I collaborated with him regarding the position of the Pill Box, fixed it, he & I were examining the plan, when suddenly a rifle shot rang out & Josephs said "I'm hit", thro the back & stomach again the sniper let fly & got another & again another, we rushed for shelter where we made a plan, waving a towel we went out to Josephs lifted him on a stretcher and I decided to immediately carry him in, we were not satisfied that the german sniper would respect the flag, but as it happened he did although I am satisfied that I had the "wind" up gad! I was deep down scared, I cannot understand why the bullet hit him instead of my self, poor chap he was hit hard & I doubt if he will get thro, under the first cover I dressed his wound, it did'nt bleed much. I have just written to his people. About 200 yds on I got back to my own sappers & having valuable information I had to leave him to his own men.

 
In a
 Behind a concrete dug out in rear of Augustus Wood lay 10 wounded Manchesters, been there 4 days, hands were rotting off, men & officers lay dead they were forgotten

11th Continued

officers of the 66 gave the wounded their assurance that they would make arrangements for their removal, 
some
 since then nothing had been done

 My sappers (Sgt Burnell) removed a number Wnglish wounded today €” it is hard toil bringing out the wounded I have tried it & know, the tracks are awful, sticky wretched mud

 Tonight I read the 103rd Psalm with a full heart its contents are more real for the experiences of the day

 The 10th go tonight over K track

215

7 or 8 wounded lay in Hamburg Farm again Manchesters, again 4 or 5 lay at the advanced concrete "Pill Box". The position is disgraceful, the 66th reported everything cleared up U here lay 21 men dying for lack of food water & medical comforts

Sgt Smith 2nd 4th East Lancashires 12th Platoon "C" Co was at the "dug out" about 10 D C020 sticking by his men heartening them up €” he is an hero

 Thro glasses I watched Bosch Snipers moving on the opposite slope, had a few shots at 900 yds did not see any result.

 Being now satisfied with my investigation I layed tape for a track old Fritzes Planes were active, he would drop lights on our positions, then within a few minutes over would come the "iron foundries" they do come too.

 On the way home I called at C.R.E. got a short sharp reception for my statements regarding line position contradicted the reports of Generals; two; to be exact gad! they did go off pop. General Monash was influenced in his final de
s
cisions regarding the attack tomorrow €” I had been there & I knew only too well

 With tomorrows attack, we will have been in 3 battles in 10 days, almost a record, Australians are much pleased, their fighting qualities are remarkable

217
Entry.191:
Brydon was Killed last night €” Had a lively day today.

 Went up into the lines leaving Ypres at 10 am with Stone & Millar, on the flat near Hamburg Fritz commenced to shell heavily, we sheltered in shell holes, Australians lay around evidently they had been shelled last night on the way to the assembly tape €” the sights were 
all
 awful I saw a man seated comfortable without head or chest. Walking on we soon realised that something had gone wrong comming up to the lines we observed that the men in reserve were crouching in shell holes €” snipers I tried to find an officer €” but they were in a "dug out" so I crawled on to a concrete "dug out" between the road & Augustus Wood. Shelling was extremely heavy here we found English wounded had lain for 4 days, An T.M.B officer gave me the dinkum oil €” the NZs had failed to advance having been held up by pill boxes on the left Ridge, our men advanced to the out skirts of the village. I saw our men retreating from the ridge the bombardment was awful, our men were by MG from the left, The German Pill Boxes were cleverly wired & the New Zealanders left their men on the wire

 The 10th Brigade suffered heavily the 10th T.M.B. lost 6 crews Lieut G.S Brown was wounded & I had a good yarn with him
Entry.192:
Continued

Planes today they are very large & were accompanied by little fighting planes Tonight they were droppig bombs on Ypres but htis is a common happening & we hardly worry over them

 Old Fritz has an "India rubber" Gun with which he shells this show, very seldom doe he seem to hit anyone, It is a high velocity chap & screams as it comes along

219

 Snipers were extremely busy & had a few pots at us €” I am getting fairly shrewd & did the kangaroo hop from shell hole to shell hole €” glad to get back, called at C.R.E. & gave them a little information regarding the 33rd they were occupying our lines, the mud on the track was awful & walking heavy, Gad I am tired. The attack was a failure
Entry.193: Had a day home, hung about doing next to nothing, wrote home Stew Matters called round today
Entry.194:
Went out this morning to fix up a mule track from "Dash Crossing" to Hamburg, had a party of infantry & Sappers Mine goodness Ive gone over some tracks but this one is the limit; horrible, dead men all the way out half buried in the mud etc, he must lamb this track with his artillery, the railway is all torn up passed near Zonnebeck like Ypres it's a heap of ruins, Fritz sent over some of his ironworks just as we got to the job & my infantry mad a bee line for the horizon its seldom I swear but I cursed those chaps over hell & dale, the dogs I know some of them only too well, All except 4 were discovered & we finished off the track, Coming back we carried in 4 wounded men one had been out there 3 days & 2 nights, Met Williams coming home also Dewar, my heel was dreadfully sore I could hardly walk home Saw a squadron of Bosch

221
Entry.195: Had a day home just hung around in the billet, Fritz put one of his indiarubber shells into our garden €” it did'nt make much of a mess the ground was too soft. Fritzes planes were extremely busy dropping bombs all over the show, wrote a few letters home. My leg is giving considerable trouble & is very painful Got 2 stars today €” dated back to August 15th
Entry.196:
Went out to duck board one of the tracks to Levi Cottage, going out he heaped in some gas shells €” mustard gas €” whilst doing the job, he "stonkered" other spots. Coming home it was the very devil everywhere we went he started to lobb shells, going up the road we "went down" to a beaut. I think it got a few chaps, that Zonnebeck - Ypres road is always a hot spot & 2 of our chaps were hit comming in. Spent a good time in billet tonight just a yarn & doing nothing

 Gill called here today he is in the 7th Lawrie is with him
Entry.197:
Had an easy day, went down to the Cathedral & Cloth Hall to get a souvenir from the Cathedral I secured a piece of oak & made ajolly fine stick it will be useful, whilst wandering among the ruins I saw a Bosch plane fall, evidently a wing had been blown off by the Archies, The day has been delightful, sun most of the day, the buildings are famous from an architectural point of view, the columns are massive & many have fallen, my stick is of oak & I cut it from one of the bannisters, it looks fine & will be interesting to the folks at home Heard today that we will be going back to Blequin & then to Armentieres for winter

223

18.10.17

 Had an easy time this morning making a pyramid from a piece of oak from the Cloth Hall, Fritz dropped some of his shells close to the billet, Went down to the Cathedral for some timber for a stick for the Major (with Moore)

 Went out over our area with Lieut Hill of the 11th Canadian Field Engineers, Old Fritz put up some solid shell fire, got a 18 lb dump on the left of the road which made some good fireworks, he shelled the area between Borry & Bremin real heavy, whilst resting behind Levi Farm he commenced to register on it giving us a warm time. I was glad to get home, to dinner & bed.
Entry.198:
Up at 3.30 am Breakfast at 4 am €” Cash made breakfast a good one too, he is a decent little chap and awfully willing, Met Lieut Hill at 4.30 am at Menin Gate €” the city wall & moat are close by. Fritz has not done much damage to it €” later at Potjige Corner I picked up 300 infantry & we moved out picking up duck boards en route, & carried them to the job €” between Van Isackere Farm and the , via 'K' Track, We walked via Jack & Jill Track, passed Greesy Rees & Finch of the 3rd Pioneers a shell had Knocked out 6 of them, just a chance shell, Fritz was quiet so we carried all our boards over the ridge, a mist hung around which was fortunate for it is under enemy observation finished off job & left for home Fritz lobbed a few shells about making it difficult to know when he intended to lobb the next Grass is already springing up I was quite surprised to notice it, Fritz shelled the road heavy shrapnell & H.E. Les Rooney is wounded & in England, Harold Whitworth is also back there shell shock

225

We expect yo go back to rest in a few days looking back over the stunts here I have been extremely fortunate of the hundreds of men I have had for working parties I have only had 2 slightly wounded, The C.R.E. Col of the
Entry.199:
Div Canadian Engineers had dinner with us tonight, he is very poeasant & aff
i
able.
Entry.200: Received orders to proceed per Motor Bike to our Rest Billets 40 miles or so back €” set off tomorrow, had a quiet time today
Entry.201: Fine day, left Ypres & getting the bike moved off, the road for the first 10 miles was extremely greasy, had lots of adventures amidst the traffic, it was always heavy on the YPRES Popernge Road Soon I left behind the wrecked houses & entered the country, the main roads are of cobbles, they shake up all the bones in a fellows body, the old motor bike eats up petrol & I had to refill two or 3 times, any old waggon which passed carried whips of petrol & oil so I had no difficulty, our Billets are at Merck St LiÃ¨vin at shich spot I arrived about 2 pm, it is a lovely rustic spot looked over the billets & selected a good one for myself for the night, the french lady was awfully kind.
Entry.202:
Rode into ST OMER & saw the lovely Cathedral, Gothic architecture, & back to , met our company & gave them the route, Had a yarn with some NZ officers re the stunts they had a rough time, the NZ Rifles moved off whilst I was there but I did not recognise any of them, they are a remarkably fine crowd

 

The officer Josephs who was sniped whilst chatting to me is getting on as well as can be expected it was his first morning in the lines since Messines €” having been wounded there €”

 The day before our company left YPRES old Fritz lambed it with heavy stuff, killed 3 sgts of the
Entry.203:
& 23 Canadian Pioneers €” a few yards from our billets, Poor old Ypres surely you have suffered enough.

227
Entry.204:
day
 28.10.17

 Church parade at Halte D'Ouve the C of E Padre preached on the text, "So I am with you always" rather good & refreshing, he referred to the recent stunts & remarked that our presence was due to the fact that God had taken care of us.

 Arriving home we heard that we were to move to Foret De Clairmarais early tomorrow, spent afternoon getting transport ready. Took the opportunity to visit Avroult to see Harry Symonds €” with the 43rd Battalion, it was about 3 kilometres over the hill, the valley looked lovely, found Symonds he had a blistered knee which was very painful €” thro kneeling in shells holes caused by Gas shells €” was glad to see him again. Stew Matters came over to afternoon tea he looked well after his spell

29.10.17

 Moved to our new quarters this morning on Motor lorries €” tres bon we all appreciated this method of travelling our route lay thro Wisernes & at Le Nieppe we debussed, a march of 1 ½ miles brought us to our new quarters €” an old aerodrome & a very bleak spot, the country around is waterlogged & low, little boats provide the method for bringing the produce from the fields as a matter of fact the country reminds one of Holland. Numerous Windmills & canals.

 Went down the road to an aerodrome, an officer showed me some of the mechanism; the planes are black & all used for night work bombing. I was surprised to learn that they weighed 1 ½ tons. the engines are 6 cylinder and are beautiful examples of English work.

229

A NZ soldier gave me a badge "Skull & Cross bones" also some German money, taken from prisoners, these I sent later to Florrie
Entry.205: Did nothing special today just hung around, examined the old mill 1711 very interesting
Entry.206:
Moore went off to Paris, lent hi 150 francs, the Padre is going to the 9th Brigade good job too he drinks to much beer at mess.

 It rained heavily & I had to go about 14 miles to the 39th and 40th Battalions to see about locations for stables, got sopping wet & cold, everything seemed awfully dull, untill I noticed the glorious autumn colours in the landscape, the thought happened to flash thro my mind "How beautiful God makes all things" tired though I was it acted like an inspiration & my old bike simply scorched home.

 Posted a gas helmet (German) home €” came from Armentieres, the case from the Ypres battlefield, also the souvenir of YPRES Cloth Hall, the Brick is from the Central tower, also the bit of shell, the lead, & the rough pyramid, I spent a long time looking for the bell couldnt find it, From the armory I dug up an old spear head which I am sending home, it must have hung on the walls for centuries, they look awful rubbish but somehow a fellow loves them, these will always have a charm because I got them myself
Entry.207:
A parade this morning & inspection of clothing.

231
Entry.208: Commenced work on a water supply scheme with about 50 men the day was wet & bitterly cold, a biting wind blew all day €” knocked off the men early as they were wet through, a portion of the track was thro a swamp
Entry.209:
Rode into ST OMER with Hayes €” my batman & spent an interesting time looking over the churches, the windows were of stained glass & simply beautiful, of course there was the usual dribble, cheap statury etc. Another Gothic Church in ruins was destroyed during the French revolution, I purchased some P.Cs for Florrie, & rode home round the FORET DE CLARMARAIS

 Purchased a few odds & ends at the Officers Clothing Store €” we have not to pay money for these they deduct it from our pay books

 Evidently the Canadians are having an awful tussle for Passchendale I knew some of the points taken

 All night long we hear the buzz & hum of aeroplanes but today they are far to common to awake interest. It is pleasant at times to watch them practising during the day.

 Our artillery working party received hurried orders to move up to the front today

233

Page I
Entry.210:
It's some days since my last diary lift €” one day I visited Arques to see the big lock over the railway, it is a massive bit of work and one which I considered unnecessary €” for they could have lifted the railway a few feet. Sentries were posted around the work & in french told me that it only worked on weekdays €” it was Sunday when I was there. The canall is fairly wide & the barges massive they must draw loaded somewhere about 6'0". Horses are sometimes used to tow them along, more frequently however human labour is used €” I have seen men women & boys pulling them along.

 Came home thro the Forest De Clairmarais the road was extremely muddy & every few yards I had to clean it away from the forks of my bike, Saw some pheasants & deer, half way thro I pulled up for lunch it was lovely sitting midst the Oak Trees enjoying a smoke €” some Havelock from home.

 One night we enjoyed a little music at the Chateau opposite, the girls play fairly well & some of our officers provided the songs €” it may at first appear amusing €” for some of us can speak good french still somehow we jog along fine

 It rains today seems to do nothing else in this country, I am amusing myself writing home & elsewhere
Entry.211:
Raining again amused myself making a walking stick from a bit of timber €” Ypres Cathedral. Rather interested to see the constellation of Orion tonight

235

 The noise of the Planes during the night effectually destroyed my sleep they must have been running too & fro all night, as I lay in my bag the memories of the recent stunts came up again clear & plain, they were extremely vivid I think they must have been produced by the fact that my Sergeant €” Burnell €” has been awarded the Military Medal I am delighted for he did his bit thoroughly & well.

8.11.17

 A new morning so I walked to Cassel €” the city on the hill which was so prominent on the march up, it is a quaint little spot & from the Casino a glorious view of the plains is obtained. it is a strange geological formation €” being a solitary hill in the centre of a great plain.

 Examined a 400 year old Windmill €” it is used for grinding flour the mechanical devices are of extreme interest & simplicity

 Rode to Le Nieppe per motor waggons €” there is so much traffic behind the lines that you can ride anywhere on the waggons. Cassel is the Hqrs of the 2nd Army Corps

 The Canadians have taken Passchendale €” good luck to them, the fights for that ridge will be remembered thro history, they have been horrible.

 Major Williams of the
Entry.212:
is to be C.R.E. to the 3rd Aust Divis our major is now senior major

 

237
Entry.213:
Moore turned up after leave in Paris, Snelgrove late of the 17th is attached to the 9th he has the same old way with him & is any thing but a general favourite

 Made arrangements to run down to Boulogne per motor bike tomorrow.
Entry.214:
The Newspapers are full of stuff re the taking of Passchendaele & say all sorts of rot, Its raining in bucketfuls had to give up hope of seeing Scott today, the weather is very cold €” Our last attack on Passchendaele was messed up by a traitor who deserted to the Germans & told everything, this is official.

 Rain cleared off a bit so I decided to set off for 
Passchend
 Boulogne made good going till I got to Drionville. here I packed the outfit & myself into a motor lorrie & we arrived at Boulogne about 3.30, Got a room at the Hotel Bourgoyne Rue de Lille & tramed out to the hospital No 14 General, walking thro the ward I heard "Hello Stan", Scottie had seen me first had afternoon tea with him & a good ole yarn, it was dark when I came out, the tram car was crowded but I hung on in spite of the continual warnings of the conductor, the electrical connections were bad & I received a heavy shock, Boulogne was in darkness so I saw very little of it, the old fortifications looked interesting & I felt a keen desire to explore.
Entry.215:
Left at 9 am bike went fairly well, covered the first 27 kilos in good time, suddenly the whole outfit seemed to fall to pieces so I pushed

239

it to Lottinghem, Had lunch with some NZ officers, met a Sergeant on the station who knew Raetihi & my people A munition train came along so I had a yarn with the driver & finally we heaved the machine among the coal & I sat on the tender untill we arrived at ST OMER (7 pm) Had tea in a Church Army Hut & set out for camp, was picked up by a waggon & finished up with a kilometer walk €” happy because I had seen my chum, Vera sent a parcel & letter, tres bon Les Rooney & Constance Moore letters received.
Entry.216:
Received a parcel from Constance Moore it is jolly kind of her to write so often, she is Lance Gills sister in law, Moore goes up to inspect the new sector today it is close to Messines

 A heavy bombardment is in progress we have heard the dull roar since early this morning Received letters from Mrs Stone & Beryl €” a parcel from Constance Moore.
Entry.217: Bombardment still continues, it is heavy & continuous, nothing doing today
Entry.218: We leave for the line tomorrow, going by Motor Lorrie, nothing doing today so I swatted a little German, It is said that Thirkell is comming as Capt to this company. Our new billets are situated near Wulverghem €” near Messines.
Entry.219:
Set out with 9th, awful mess regarding 10th transport, I lost touch with it altogether later it joined us up, Camped for night on Sylvester Hazebrouck Road

Buried in same grave as Cecil Dunn

 A E Smith 931 40th Batt

 H Wilson 2171 "

 Bowring 548 " "

241
Entry.220: Finished off march to our camp near Wulverghem 10.d 0.0. from here we can see Messines, the dull roar of artillery is constant, the famous Hill 63 is close, our camp is comfortable & my men are in separate little possies & are quite content, we are in shelters of Elephant iron & have stoves, tres bon, the English R Engrs left quite an amount of nice furniture & our mess looks tip top.
Entry.221: Went out to the trenches this morning 4 miles out (2 miles of duckboards) on south side of the River Douve, it was misty, machine guns would swing along & the bullets sang overhead, I walked out over the top & had a good cruise round the infantry have a rough time but look comfortable they live in holes dug into the walls of the trench, here the sector is quiet, some of the trenches are wet & sloppy, Met Bill Orchard
Entry.222:
Went out again with Cpt Grey and Lieut Mahy met Jim Mundy old Geelong chap, Thirkell may come to this company Read 46th Psalm €” I like it very much, am living with Snellgrove, had a look for Cecil Dunns grave & found one at the point given to me it is not marked, the are at the head of the grave, the spot is sheltered and quiet & I intend to send a leaf from a plant close by to his people whilst chasing round I met Capt Driver who is associated with the graves Registration Work he volunteered his assistance, later he wrote stating that he had no official information of the spot

 Old Fritz is dropping bombs as I write, we lose no sleep over these bouquets

 Warnton Tower (German) overlooks our trenches, direct hits by our artillery fail to it, it is a fine observation post & gives the Bosch a distinct advantage in our sector.

Picked up some samples of German entanglements for the folks at home near La Potteries Farm 1 mile south of Messines near La Douve River.

243
Entry.224: Wandered over the country in the left Sector, Sgt Burnell returned from England, taped with him the switch from Av to Ugly Av, it was a great job crawling on my tummy between the lines, Also made a reconnaissance of the Support line €” no bon up to the eyes in mud, where it had fallen we had to crawl on the surface, Warnton Tower looks lovely when you are crawling along. Came back thro the Iron Gate and past Hyde Park Corner, the Caracombs are interesting Ploegstreet Wood looks well, the works within it are wonderful, all breastwork & must have taken months to complete
Entry.225: Cruised round today up Ash Avenue past Antons Fm Long Ruin to Fuze Cottage, The craters are immense, they were fired during the Messines Stunt, huge concrete dug outs were crumpled & debris lies all over the place. La Potteries Fm must have been a very strong point, I examined it rather carefully today, Our men worked on a miserable bit of drainage from Useful Trench, Met Lieut Swan
Entry.226:
Commenced the new trench tonight, Fritz gave little trouble, his verry lights were numerous in the next sector, in ours he traversed frequently with Machine gun fire €” no bon, they swish the 
gun
 bullets to and fro in the hope of getting working parties, I was out in the field 12 hours

 

245
Entry.227: Went out with the Major to the trenches €” he soon gets the wind up
Entry.228:
Went out with Moore this morning a stiff wind was blowing & I was glad to get home, Enjoyed a good yarn with Onebeck a new Belgium interpreter, he told me of the evacuation of Antwerp it must have been terrible.

 Saw The Only Way a famous trench during the Messines Stunt

 My Sergeant brought in a bit of barbed wire from the old german front line, I secured a bit of entanglement saw toothed €” sent them both home
Entry.229: Went up Kemmel a high hill about 4 miles from Neuve Eglise, the scene from the crown is charming, I watched our shells bursting on Roulers.
Entry.230:
Walked over to Ravelsberg to see Sapper Hamilton he had dinner with me & we enjoyed a good yarn

 Called on Capt Harry Storrer? a Geelong chum of mine €” he was just going up in a plane
Entry.231:
Went out to the craters today, road as usual muddy, enjoyed the walk, saw Comines behind the german lines, a balloon got away and floated off towards Belgium, Fritz shelled it pretty solid

247
Entry.232:
Saw Malcolm, Jenkins (No 2) Holder & Robinson a few days ago

 Jack Frost is doing his best & the weather has turned cold

 A Fritz plane scattered Newspapers over back areas today

 Had afternoon tea down at 'C' Co 40th Batt with Swann

 The sun set tonight was delightful
Entry.233:
Met Williams up the line this morning and was sorry to hear that Capt Storrer had been killed

 Old Fritz was giving Worn Trench fits but we still went there, & after--wards visited the different jobs, it has been fine for a couple of days
Entry.234:
Just hung about all day translated a French leading article

10.1217

Major returned from Paris Fritz sent over balloons & dropped papers I hav'nt managed to far to get any. Had quite a number of letters from home
Entry.235:
Attracted by the noise of outside I walked out of my Dugout & saw a fleet of Gothes overhead, they are big machines & have 2 engines, they dropped bombs on Hill 63 Plooegstreert wood & Neuve Eglise killing & wounding many men. I saw one come down in flames the wings fluttered down separately from where I stood it

 

249

seemed to fall in Ploegsteert wood but later we learned that it fell in "No Mans Land.
Entry.236: Had a good old wander round today, With Cpl Lynch I walked over to the Catacombs €” Hyde Park Corner €” these are galleries driven into the hill 63 & were carried out by Australians they will hold easily a full batallion of men & here the reserve co rested during the Messines Stunt Saw Jim Mundy
Entry.237:
T.M.B. & had a good old yarn with him

 The tunnels nearer Red Lodge were more primitive but were in good trim

 The whole of the catacombs are llighted by electricity

 Wandered round to the front of hill 63 to an old aeroplane & picked out a couple of fittings for souvenirs.
Entry.238:
Nothing doing, they say that Fritz is shelling Bailleul, the civil population are stricken & many have been killed.

 A great amount of activity has been noticed behind Fritzies lines & there is some speculation as to whether he will attempt to break thro here

251
Entry.239: The 10th went out today to Watts lines & the
Entry.240:
came in. With Lawrie I wandered over the left sector Old Fritz was extraordinary quiet

 Met Major Webb, an ex ^antartic man went down there with Mawson he knew Sam Steel well having lectured with him at Canterbury College

 Christian & Lawrie I knew in Sydney. I knew in Brightlingsea he is now a Captain

 The day was fine & I quite enjoyed the walk round, Met Col Lord of the 40th & quite a number of officers I had made the acquaintance of in the lines, the
Entry.242:
Shifted down to Watts lines situated in the main Armentiers Ballieul Road It snowed during the afternoon. I walked to Steenwerck to see Col Clogson re an additional defencive scheme behind the present lines.

 There was some delay re the shifting my gear, our new hut is of wood & will be very comfortable

 Gothas came over during the afternoon, they seem to like this part of the world.

253
Entry.243: Went out on some Corp work at Wytschacte, the country was extremely interesting I saw two or 3 of the huge craters, one or two failed to explode & notices are up warning people not to go within certain distances of certain fences.
Entry.244: Went our with Col Clogstone in a car to a point south of Plougsteert wood to select a position for a strong point perchance old Fritz should come thro I enjoyed the trip, the weather was bitter cold & I fell thro the ice in a drain this did'nt affect me very much €” rather I hadnt done all the same
Entry.245:
Went out with Cpl Oliphant to 
Wyse
 Wytschaete, the morning was frosty & cold, I was delighted with the landscape it looked charming, a mist thickened as the day came on, after calling at one job we went over to look at a huge crater, 330 paces round the lip, it was a perfect cone & reminded one of an extinct volcano, We lost our way in the mist, met Major Gould late of the 17th €” a prigg €”

255
Entry.246: Spent the day cruising round, went to Steenwerck during the afternoon, Fritz shelled the dump. Spent evening with Davison of the Army Troops Co
Entry.247: Went out to the country between Ploughsteert Wood and LE Biset on a reconn, or with General White Col Milne, Col Clogstone to select lines & positions for second lines of Corp Defense very interesting
Entry.248:
Made reconnaissance of trench between Plougsteert and Support Farm.

 Xmas dinner with my section, everything went off beautifully & was most excellent

25.12.17

 Spent most of the day on the line, it blew a gale most of the time, rain hail snow, real xmas weather when you have a good fire to sit close to,

 No 1 had their dinner it was good but resolved itself quickly into a vulgar parody, Most of our officers were drunk & made fools of themselves

 The ground is white with snow & the landscape presents quite a different appearance

 An old ruined Convent at Le Biset interested me in it were a number of books I picked up one "En Terre Promise" for study, also a visiting card which I sent home, Ive spent Xmas in some quiet places

257

but this is the most unique, Fritz was quiet all day, I read tonight a portion of the 1st chapter in Matthew ^ also the
Entry.250:
The day opened badly, it snowed fairly heavily, the country is covered later it ceased but the cold kept on

 I went out to the laundry at Le Biset & waited for 1 hr for Col Clogstone Met General Paton Major Harris & had a good old yarn with . Met him near the Motor Car Corner. He was doing a wiring job from the River Lys to-wards the lines, ArmentiÃ¨res showed up very clearly
Entry.251: Nothing doing, very cold, Snow lay around all day, Saw Clogstun during the afternoon, quite enjoy his company.
Entry.252:
Went out to Le Biset met Elsum & after looking over the wire we had lunch in a ruined factory and walked into Armentieres, The town has been well battered €” nothing like so much as Ypres €” but it will be te deuce of a job patching up the houses we walked down to ½ past eleven Square, the area is evacuated & we only saw 4 soldiers, I walked into the Hotel de Ville & took a small thermometer for a souvenir, the houses are mostly furnished, pictures hang on the walls & everything looks as if the people had gone hurriedly. Fritz gassed the civilians here

259
Entry.253:
Walked out to Le Biset this morning, had lunch in a ruined house near the convent.

 Fritz gassed farms close handy today Rebecque Farm got a good dose
Entry.254:
Went into Armentiere again today had a good old walk round, looked into the Notre Dame (the Cathedral) seeing a plaister hand from one of the alters on the floor I picked it up it was practically not injured intend to send it home, I also got a cover for Florrie to make a cushion out off it, Old Fritz well & truly aimed at the Cathedral but the strange part is that the falling debris has not injured the alters, the building is of excellent design

 Met Thirkell now Capt of the eleventh in there. Met Gillisper near Rebecque
Entry.255:
Went into Bailleul to the Aerodromes to see Buckland had lunch with him

 Comming back I called on May Hamiltons brother & enjoyed a cup of coffee with him.

 The Co sergeants gave us a dinner tonight €” pretty fair but I'm tired of the sight of a spread

 Read the old 46th Psalm, I like it very much.
Entry.256:
Went towards Wyschacte this morning to meet an artillery officer regarding a road for his "Grannie" most excellent trip, saw 2 more of the famous Messines craters

 I'm off to Paris on Friday next

261
Entry.258: Came back again to Watts Lines
Entry.259: Went out to examine the Sector up Vancouver Track with Christian & Gill, Fritz "minnied" the Sugar Refinery & in retalliation we swamped Warnton with 18 pounders it was interesting, met Deacon comming home I tried to shave myself with the edge of my tin hat & was taken to hospital near Bailleul
Entry.261: We shift back to our old lines beautiful day
Entry.262: Met Parkinson & Deacon they are moving back to Boulogne to Rest, we are having a dreary time nothing doing, today there is a slight frost
Entry.263:
6
.2.18

 They intend to give me the drivers. Went up the line todaay with Sgt Bryson. Examined country for wire between Flattened Farm & Trois Teulliul it was soft & muddy we walked up the Vancouver Track to the rear of La Basse Ville on the top old Fritz did not seem to worry. Went by the Ultimo Lane to Company Headquarters at

Capt. Fairweather had charge of the raid for the
Entry.264:
263

road 17d 5.9. trip was most interesting Saw a cock pheasant 500 yds in rear of Front line
Entry.265:
Wandered out again this morning up the Ultimo Avenue.. Parties were on surface at St YVES, after we had been gone about 2 minutes he laid into them with shrapnel, gas & H.E. we heard them calling for stretcher bearers, serve them right, the gun was situated behind heard the report of the gun before the shells landed.

 Thro an observation post at the Iron Gate I watched fritz working, most interesting. Selected a machine gun shelter in Ultimo Lane.

 tongiht we watched the Artillery bombardment & Fritzies Verry lights evidently we were raiding him somewhere down Armentieres way.
Entry.266:
Left here at 3 pm for to meet Capt Fairweather at Chasseur at 5.30 pm Wandered across from Ultimo to Sunken Farm via another farm at 17b 0.5. a few dead lay around, Fritz minnied La Basse Ville, Our own machine guns turned on us €” silly cows they evidently had the wind up.

 Met Fairweather & walked down past the station & along the Warneton Road, stumbling & sliding over the debris

 My sergeant was lost in No Mans land for 1 ½ hrs €” Sgt 

 Glad to get home, mud up to the eyes

265
Entry.267:
Went out again tonight, cleared a track for the wounded €” from a projected raid €” along road past La Truie Farm to Sugar Refinery & from there along Warnton Road up to Ultimo Lane, beyond a few spurts of MG & Verry lights €” no trouble

 The wiring from Chasseur Cab to Railway started well but in the darkness the infantry cleared out, will cure this

 Old Fritz knocked out the Artillery at Antons Farm, he was on the edge of the rise all afternoon later he lobbed a shell among a crowd of 40th chaps at Prowse Point they were repairing the tramway €” killed one chap wounded 3 or 4, I watched one artillery stonker :In den Rooster Cab" near Warneton €” very interesting.
Entry.268: Had an easy day €” one of our chaps was injured tonight - Russell of No 4 section
Entry.269:
Went out with Sgt Kay, took him "to hold the candle" he is a windy crow even tho he did win a M.M. absolute rot, walked up to Concrete O.P. Oldt Fritz was shelling Prowse P

267

from here we walked up Ultimo Avenue to the R.A.P. here we left the trench & walked overland along a duck board track towards Vancouver Track, old Fritz saw us, put a whissbang on the right, another on the left, then one right thro the duck boards €” awfully neat €” just about 40 feet to our rear this put the wind right into the sergeant who quivered like a leaf

 Walked over to Trois Tilleuls Farm a strong Pill Box round which some heavy fighting occured, the moat is still formidable examined the old Bosch trenches Uncle Support, they are much knocked about by artillery.

 Calder goes to the
Entry.270:
Valentine comes to our crowd

 12 months ago today since we left Australia.

 About 9 pm, Van Rosendohl, Phillips and myself walked out to Heath Trench on Hill 63 to watch the Bombardment for the raid from left of La Basse Ville in Warneton, simultaneously our guns opened at 10 pm, the barrage looked awful, Verry lights red green white went up in hundreds right along the line of front everything we had set to work, Minnies could be seen but not heard, Fritzies missiles came across from Deulemont there trajectory was clearly defined, Fritz seemed to have some shells which scattered molten metal

269

we watched the stunt spellbound for ¾ hour & as it died down began to think of comming home, Fritz thought about this too & lambed the road 3 times he splashed us with mud he only fired about 6 shells our way but they were mighty close. Gun flashes were continuous, thro glasses the horizon seemed to be a continuous convulsion,
Entry.271:
Raid highly successful. 33 prisoners, many killed, we lost 6 killed (Off Crow & Dixson) about 20 wounded

 Hung around Camp doing nothing

 Snellgrove put on La Basse Ville Defense I had to take up rear work about the
Entry.273:
Snellgrove fell off his horse I had to take up work at La Basseville including his title of R.T.O. La Basse Ville Major Story is Town Major, Story is a fine chap & in the succeeding 5 days we had many an adventure, Machine gun bullets, gas snipers & artillery barrage, We are on special work La Basse Ville is the key to the whole of the divisional front & is a tricky spot, We have held it since July last & nothing of a definite defense scheme has been carried out or even started this portion is waterlogged country & is especially adapted to Breastwork, hidden

60 completed as above

by 82 men of the 39th

including salvaging of material

271

saps are in progress, the front line along has 4'0" of water & mud in it the line from the Warneton Road to left dos'nt exist Nos 7,8 & 9 posts are absolutely awful men cannot move to them in the day time, no movement except in Ultimo Avenue is permitted in time, the men in the posts are absolutely isolated all day & in case of attack would be cut off entirely, at night Nos 7,8 & 9 have to be approached cautiously, Fritz sweeps the intervening ground with light MGs Snipers are particularly active one bailed us up on the night 15/16. The road junction at La Basseville is a favourite spot for Fritzies MG Bullets & here he gave us a merry 5 minutes, the Warneton La Basseville road is controlled by his guns & he sweeps the track occasionally Minnies lobb frequently & keep you moving

 On the night 18/19 82 men of the 39th put in 60x of completed trench in York Way I was particularly pleased with the work.

 Major Story ceased on the
Entry.274: & handed over to Major Patterson, I am happy to have been associated with Story
Entry.275:
Completed another 80x of York Av carried materials 3 miles from Racine

 Wired 180x in front of Posts 7,8,9 fairly quiet, night very wet & cold
Entry.276: my birthday, Auntie Miss? Gloria? sent me a pork pie, had a day off due to changeing of battalions
Entry.277: Whilst awaiting a working party at Way La Basse Ville, I got copped in a Minnie barrage, it is a nerve racking experience, Fritz gave us a solid time also sent gas shells, after 15 minutes I managed to get along Ultimo, down Vancouver, up track to R.A.P. & home Met Johnny Ride today he looks well and hearty, was glad to get back to my dug out at St YVES.
